PART II - CODE OF ORDINANCES PART II - CODE OF ORDINANCES SUBPART A - GENERAL ORDINANCES

div.head: Chapter 1 - GENERAL PROVISIONS
div.p: Sec. 1-1. - Designation and citation of Code. The ordinances embraced in this and the following chapters shall constitute and be designated "The Code of Polk County, Georgia," may be so cited. State Law reference— Codification requirements, O.C.G.A. § 36-80-19. Sec. 1-2. - Definitions and rules of construction. In the construction of this Code and of all ordinances, the rules of construction and definitions set out in this section shall be observed. The rules of construction and definitions set out in this section shall not be applied to any section of this Code which shall contain any express provisions excluding such construction or where the subject matter or context of such section may be repugnant thereto. Generally. The ordinary signification shall be applied to all words, except words of art or words connected with a particular trade or subject matter when they shall have the signification attached to them by experts in such trade or with reference to such subject matter. In all interpretations the courts shall look diligently for the intention of the council, keeping in view, at all times, the old law, the evil and the remedy. Grammatical errors shall not vitiate, and a transposition of words and clauses may be resorted to when the sentence or clause is without meaning as it stands. State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 1-3-1(a), (b). Liberal construction; minimum requirements; overlapping provisions . All general provisions, terms, phrases and expressions contained in this Code shall be liberally construed in order that the true intent and meaning of the board of commissioners may be fully carried out. In the interpretation and application of any provision of this Code, they shall be held to be the minimum requirements adopted for the promotion of the public health, safety, comfort, convenience and general welfare. Where any provision of this Code imposes greater restrictions upon the subject matter than the other provisions of this Code, the provision imposing the greater restriction or regulation shall be deemed to be controlling. The specific controls over the general. As soon as possible. The term "as soon as possible" means within a reasonable time, having due regard to all the circumstances. State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 1-3-3(5). Board of Commissioners. The term "Board of Commissioners" means the Board of Commissioners of the county. Code. The term "Code" means The Code of Polk County, Georgia, as designated in section 1-1. The Code consists of subparts A and B. Computation of time. When a number of days is prescribed for the exercise of any privilege or the discharge of any duty, only the first or last day shall be counted. If the last day shall fall on Saturday or Sunday, the party having such privilege or duty shall have through the following Monday to exercise such privilege or to discharge the duty. When the last day prescribed for such action shall fall on a public or legal holiday as set forth in state law, the party having such privilege or duty shall have through the following business day to exercise such privilege or to discharge the duty. When the period of time prescribed is less than seven days, an intermediate Saturday, Sunday and legal holiday shall be excluded in the computation. State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 1-3-1(d)(3). Conjunctions. Where a provision involves two or more items, conditions, provisions or events connected by the conjunction "and," "or" or "either . . . or," the conjunction shall be interpreted as follows, provided in appropriate cases the terms "and" and "or" are interchangeable: (1) The term "and" indicates that all the connected items, conditions, provisions or events shall apply. (2) The term "or" indicates that the connected items, conditions, provisions or events may apply singly or in any combination. (3) The term "either . . . or" indicates that the connected items, conditions, provisions or events shall apply singly, but not in combination. County. The term "county" means Polk County, Georgia. Delegation of authority. Whenever a provision appears requiring a county officer or county employee to do some act, it is to be construed to authorize the officer or employee to designate, delegate and authorize subordinates to perform the required act. Following . The term "following" means next after. State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 1-3-3(8). Gender. Words of one gender include words of all other genders. State Law reference— Gender, O.C.G.A. § 1-3-1(d)(4). Joint authority. A joint authority given to any number of persons or officers may be executed by a majority of them, unless it is otherwise declared. State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 1-3-1(d)(5). Keeper and proprietor . The terms "keeper" and "proprietor" means persons, whether acting by themselves or acting as a servant, agent or employee. May. The term "may" is to be construed as being permissive. State Law reference— Definition of "may," O.C.G.A. § 1-3-3(10). Month. The term "month" means a calendar month. State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 1-3-3(11). Must. The term "must" is to be construed as being mandatory. Number. The singular and plural number includes the other, unless expressly excluded. State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 1-3-1(d)(6). Oath. The term "oath" includes an affirmation. State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 1-3-3(12). O.C.G.A. The abbreviation "O.C.G.A." means the Official Code of Georgia Annotated, as amended. Officials, employees, boards, commissions or other agencies . Whenever reference is made to officials, employees, boards, commissions or other agencies by title only, the reference refers to the officials, employees, boards, commissions or other agencies of the county. Ordinance. The terms "ordinance" and "resolution" are interchangeable. Owner. The term "owner," as applied to a building or land, includes any part owner, joint owner, tenant in common, tenant in partnership or joint tenant of the whole or of a part of the building or land. Person. The term "person" includes any association, club, society, firm, corporation, limited liability company, partnership or body politic and corporate, as well as an individual. State Law reference— Definition of "person," O.C.G.A. § 1-3-3(14). Personal property. The term "personal property" includes every species of property except real property. Preceding . The term "preceding" means next before. State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 1-3-3(15). Property. The term "property" includes real and personal property. State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 1-3-3(16). Public place. The term "public place" includes any place that the public is invited or permitted to go or congregate. Real property. The term "real property" includes lands, tenements and hereditaments. Shall. The term "shall" is to be construed as being mandatory. Sidewalk. The term "sidewalk" means any portion of a street between the curbline and the adjacent property line, intended for the use of pedestrians, excluding parkways. Signature or subscription. The terms "signature" and "subscription" include the mark of an illiterate or infirm person. State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 1-3-3(19). State. The term "state" means the state of Georgia. Street or road . The terms "street" and "road" include any street, avenue, boulevard, road, alley, lane, viaduct and any other public highway in the county, including, but not limited to, the paved or improved surfaces thereof. Tenant or occupant. The term "tenant" or "occupant," applied to a building or land, includes any person holding a written or oral lease of or who occupies the whole or a part of a building or land, either alone or with others. Tense. The term "tense" means words used in the past or present tense include the future, as well as the past and present. State Law reference— Tense of words, O.C.G.A. § 1-3-1(d)(7). Week. The term "week" means seven days. Will. The term "will" is to be construed as being mandatory. Writing. The term "writing" includes printing and all numerals. State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 1-3-3(23). Year. The term "year" means a calendar year. State Law reference— Similar provisions, O.C.G.A. § 1-3-3(24). Sec. 1-3. - Catchlines of sections, effect of history notes, references in code. (a) The catchlines of the several sections of this Code in boldface type are intended as mere catchwords to indicate the contents of the sections and shall not be deemed or taken to be titles of such sections nor as any part of such sections nor, unless expressly so provided, shall they be so deemed when any of such sections, including the catchlines, are amended or reenacted. (b) The history or source notes appearing in parentheses after sections in this Code are not intended to have any legal effect but are merely intended to indicate the source of matter contained in the section. Editor's notes, cross references, and state law references which appear after sections or subsections of this Code or which otherwise appear in footnote form are provided for the convenience of the user of this Code and have no legal effect. (c) All references to chapters, articles, divisions, subdivisions or sections are to chapters, articles, divisions, subdivisions or sections of this Code, unless otherwise specified. Sec. 1-4. - Effect of repeal of ordinances. The repeal of an ordinance shall not revive any ordinance in force before or at the time the ordinance repealed took effect. The repeal of an ordinance shall not affect any punishment or penalty incurred before the repeal took effect or any suit, prosecution or proceeding pending at the time of the repeal for an offense committed or cause of action arising under the ordinance repealed. Sec. 1-5. - Amendments to code; effect of new ordinances; amendatory language. (a) All ordinances adopted subsequent to this Code that amend, repeal or in any way affect this Code may be numbered in accordance with the numbering system of this Code and printed for inclusion in this Code. The subsequent ordinances as numbered and printed or omitted, in the case of repeal, shall be prima facie evidence of these subsequent ordinances or resolutions until such time that this Code and subsequent ordinances numbered or omitted are readopted as a new Code. (b) Amendments to any of the provisions of this Code may be made by amending those provisions by specific reference to the section number of this Code in the following language: "Section ________ of The Code of Polk County, Georgia, is hereby amended to read as follows: . . .." The new provisions may then be set out in full as desired. (c) If a new section not heretofore existing in the Code is to be added, the following language may be used: "The Code of Polk County, Georgia, is hereby amended by adding a section (or chapter, article, division or subdivision, as appropriate) to be numbered ________, that reads as follows: . . .." The new material may then be set out in full as desired. (d) All sections, subdivisions, divisions, articles or chapters desired to be repealed should be specifically repealed by section, subdivision, division, article or chapter number, as the case may be, or by setting them out at length in the repealing ordinance. Sec. 1-6. - Supplementation of code. (a) Supplements to this Code shall be prepared and printed whenever authorized or directed by the county. A supplement to the Code shall include all substantive permanent and general parts of ordinances adopted during the period covered by the supplement and all changes made thereby in the Code. The pages of a supplement shall be so numbered that they will fit properly into the Code and will, where necessary, replace pages which have become obsolete or partially obsolete, and the new pages shall be so prepared that, when they have been inserted, the Code will be current through the date of the adoption of the latest ordinance included in the supplement. (b) In preparing a supplement to this Code, all portions of the Code that have been repealed shall be excluded from the Code by the omission thereof from reprinted pages. (c) When preparing a supplement to this Code, the person authorized to prepare the supplement may make formal, nonsubstantive changes in ordinances or resolutions and parts of ordinances or resolutions included in the supplement, insofar as it is necessary to do so to embody them into a unified Code. For example, the person may: (1) Organize the ordinance material into appropriate subdivisions. (2) Provide appropriate catchlines, headings and titles for sections and other subdivisions of the Code printed in the supplement and make changes in such catchlines, headings and titles. (3) Assign appropriate numbers to sections and other subdivisions to be inserted in the Code and, where necessary to accommodate new material, change existing section or other subdivision numbers. (4) Change the words "this ordinance" or words of the same meaning to "this chapter," "this article," "this division," etc., as the case may be, or to "sections ____________ to ____________ " (inserting section numbers to indicate the sections of the Code that embody the substantive sections of the ordinance incorporated into the Code). (5) Make other nonsubstantive changes necessary to preserve the original meaning of ordinances inserted into the Code. (d) In no case shall the person make any change in the meaning or effect of ordinance material included in the supplement or already embodied in the Code. Sec. 1-7. - General penalty; continuing violations. (a) In this section, the term "violation of this Code" means: (1) Doing an act that is prohibited or made or declared unlawful, an offense or a misdemeanor by ordinance or by rule or regulation authorized by ordinance; (2) Failure to perform an act that is required to be performed by ordinance or by rule or regulation authorized by ordinance; or (3) Failure to perform an act if the failure is declared a misdemeanor or an offense or unlawful by ordinance or by rule or regulation authorized by ordinance. (b) In this section, the term "violation of this Code" does not include the failure of a county officer or county employee to perform an official duty, unless it is provided that failure to perform the duty is to be punished as provided in this section or it is clear from the context that it is the intent to impose the penalty provided for in this section upon the officer or employee. (c) Except as otherwise provided: (1) A person convicted of a violation of this Code shall be punished by a fine not exceeding $1,000.00 or imprisonment for a term not exceeding 60 days, or any combination thereof. (2) With respect to violations of this Code that are continuous with respect to time, each day the violation continues is a separate offense. (3) With respect to violations of this Code that are not continuous with respect to time, each act is a separate offense. (d) The imposition of a penalty does not prevent revocation or suspension of a license, permit or franchise or other administrative sanctions. (e) Violations of this Code that are continuous with respect to time are a public nuisance and may be abated by injunctive or other equitable relief and by such other means as are provided by law. The imposition of a penalty does not prevent equitable relief. (Ord. of 8-3-1999, § 1) State Law reference— Limitations on penalties, O.C.G.A. § 36-1-20(b). Sec. 1-8. - Severability of code. The sections, paragraphs, sentences, clauses and phrases of this Code are severable, and if any phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or section of this Code shall be declared unconstitutional, invalid or otherwise unenforceable by the valid judgment or decree of any court of competent jurisdiction, that unconstitutionality, invalidity or unenforceability shall not affect any of the remaining phrases, clauses, sentences, paragraphs or sections of this Code, since they would have been enacted without the incorporation in this Code of the unconstitutional, invalid or unenforceable phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or section. Sec. 1-9. - Provisions considered as continuations of existing ordinances. The provisions appearing in this Code, insofar as they are the same as those of ordinances and resolutions existing at the time of adoption of this Code, shall be considered as continuations thereof and not as new enactments. Sec. 1-10. - Prior offenses, penalties, contracts or rights not affected by adoption of code. (a) Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall affect any offense or act committed or done or any penalty or forfeiture incurred or any contract or right established or accruing before the effective date of this Code. (b) The adoption of this Code shall not be interpreted as authorizing or permitting any use or the continuance of any use of a structure or premises in violation of any ordinance or resolution in effect on the date of adoption of this Code. Sec. 1-11. - Certain ordinances not affected by code. Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code affects the validity of any of the following ordinances or portions of ordinances, which ordinances or portions of ordinances continue in full force and effect to the same extent as if published at length in this Code: (1) Promising or guaranteeing the payment of money or authorizing the issuance of bonds or other instruments of indebtedness. (2) Authorizing or approving any contract, deed, or agreement. (3) Granting any right or franchise. (4) Making or approving any appropriation or budget. (5) Providing for salaries or other employee benefits not codified in this Code. (6) Adopting or amending the comprehensive plan. (7) Levying or imposing any special assessment. (8) Dedicating, establishing naming, locating, relocating, opening, paving, widening, repairing or vacating any street, sidewalk or alley. (9) Dedicating, accepting or vacating any plat or subdivision. (10) Levying, imposing or otherwise relating to taxes not codified in this Code. (11) Pertaining to zoning or subdivisions. (12) That is temporary, although general in effect. (13) That is special, although permanent in effect. (14) The purpose of which has been accomplished. Sec. 1-12. - Authority. (a) The governing authority of each county, for the purpose of protecting and preserving the public health, safety, and welfare, is authorized to adopt ordinances for the governing and policing of the unincorporated areas of the county, violations of which ordinances may be punished by fine or imprisonment or both. Without limiting the generality of the foregoing, such ordinances may provide for traffic regulation, including adoption of the uniform rules of the road under O.C.G.A. title 40, ch. 6 (O.C.G.A. § 40-6-1 et seq.), may provide for the regulation and control of litter in the same manner as municipal ordinances under O.C.G.A. § 16-7-48, and may provide for the implementation and enforcement of any power or duty vested in the county governing authority. (Ord. of 5-8-2007) State Law reference— Ordinances for governing and policing of unincorporated areas of county, O.C.G.A. § 36-1-20. Sec. 1-13. - Enforcement. A county governing authority shall have the power to authorize any of the officers, agents, and employees of the county to serve, in any manner prescribed by applicable law, any process, summons, notice, or order on all persons, as defined in O.C.G.A. § 1-3-3, therein named, when: (1) The paper to be served arises out of or relates to an activity or condition conducted or maintained by such person within the territorial jurisdiction of the county in violation of an applicable law or ordinance covering the following: public housing, building, electrical, plumbing, heating, ventilating, air-conditioning, air and water pollution control, solid waste management, and other technical or environmental codes; county business, occupation, and professional license tax ordinances; county privilege license or permit ordinances; or ordinances providing for the protection of facilities for the treatment or wholesale or retail distribution of water from tampering or theft which may arise either from a single isolated act or omission or from an activity or condition; (2) The paper to be served originates in or is issued under the authority of the department or branch of county government employing such officer, agent, or employee; and (3) Each and every day the condition is maintained or the activity is conducted is made a separate county offense by applicable law or ordinance. (Ord. of 5-8-2007) State Law reference— Authorization for service of process, O.C.G.A. § 36-5-26. Sec. 1-14. - Court. Each magistrate court and each magistrate thereof shall have jurisdiction and power over the following matters: (1) The hearing of applications for and the issuance of arrest and search warrants; (2) Issuance of warrants and related proceedings as provided in O.C.G.A. title 17, ch. 6, art. 4 (O.C.G.A. § 17-6-4 et seq.), of relating to bonds for good behavior and bonds to keep the peace; (3) The holding of courts of inquiry; and (4) The trial of charges of violations of county ordinances and penal ordinances of state authorities. (Ord. of 5-8-2007) State Law reference— Jurisdiction, O.C.G.A. § 15-10-2. Sec. 1-15. - Punishment. (a) This section governs trials of violations of county ordinances and ordinances of state authorities, which violations may be punished by incarceration or monetary penalty. Nothing in this chapter shall grant to any county or state authority more authority to enact or enforce such ordinances than the county or state authority has independently of this chapter. The punishment imposed for any ordinance violation shall not exceed a fine of $1,000.00 or six months' imprisonment or both, provided the judge shall probate not less than 120 days of any sentence imposed, except as otherwise provided by general law, and shall not exceed the maximum punishment specified by the ordinance. In the event a sentence is revoked, a defendant shall not serve more than 60 days in a county jail. (Ord. of 5-8-2007) State Law reference— Applicability of article; suspended sentences, O.C.G.A. § 15-10-60. Sec. 1-16. - Definitions. Unless otherwise stated in the ordinance, we have adopted the definitions set down in the O.C.G.A. § 16-1-3. (Ord. of 5-8-2007)

div.head: Chapter 2 - ADMINISTRATION
div.p:
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Sec. 2-1. - Additional penalties for ordinance violations. The provisions of the Jail Construction and Staffing Act (O.C.G.A. § 15-21-90 et seq.) are hereby placed into effect and the additional penalties provided for in such act are hereby imposed and shall be collected as provided for in such act. The funds collected pursuant to such article shall be expended for the purposes provided for in such act. (Res. of 6-30-1990) Secs. 2-2—2-20. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - BOARD OF COMMISSIONERS
Sec. 2-21. - Placement on agenda. (a) Any person wishing to be placed on the agenda of a county commission meeting shall make a request to the county clerk no later than noon on Tuesday of the week preceding a scheduled meeting on Monday or Tuesday; or at other times, by noon on the last working day before the day of the meeting. The person shall provide a name, address and general reason or topic for appearing at the meeting. (b) The board of commissioners has the right to deny a person's request to appear before the board if the reason for the appearance or topic to be discussed is frivolous or otherwise inappropriate. (c) The chairman approves the tentative agenda for meetings and the board approves the final agenda for the regular meeting. (Code 1974, § 2-16; Mo. of 1-5-1971; Ord. of 6-7-2011(1); Ord. No. 2018-05, § 1, 3-6-2018) Sec. 2-22. - Robert's rules of order. The board of commissioners hereby adopts Robert's Rules of Order as parliamentary procedure for board meetings. (Code 1974, § 2-17; Mo. of 1-14-1966) Sec. 2-23. - Types of meetings. (a) Open meetings. All meetings of the board of commissioners shall be held in accordance with state law. The public at all times shall be afforded access to all meetings other than executive sessions. (b) Executive sessions. As provided for by law the commission may close a portion of a meeting to discuss certain topics that are exempted from the Open Meetings Law. The following topics qualify for such exemption: (1) Pending or potential litigation. The commission may close a meeting to discuss with legal counsel a real or tangible threat of legal action. (2) Personnel matters. Personnel issues as provided for by law may be discussed in an executive session. Votes on personnel matters must be taken in an open meeting. (3) Real estate acquisition. The commission may close a meeting to discuss the future purchase of real estate. Minutes are required to be kept of the real estate executive session, and such minutes shall be made available for public inspection except any portion of the minutes identifying the real estate at issue may be redacted until such time the transaction is complete or abandoned. (4) Public security data. The commission may close a meeting to review or discuss records or plans that, if made public, would endanger life or property by compromising security against sabotage, criminal acts, or terrorist acts. (c) Executive session procedures. Entering an executive session requires a majority affirmative vote of the commissioners in an open meeting. (1) The minutes of the open meeting shall record the names of commissioners present, those voting, and the reason for the session. (2) Commissioners, the county clerk, the county manager, and other individuals invited by a majority of the commissioners are included on executive sessions. The county attorney, or other legal counsel, must be present in session pertaining to litigation. (3) Only the exempt topic(s) announced in the open meeting shall be discussed. If a commissioner persists in discussing non-exempt topics, the chairman shall immediately adjourn the session. (4) The chairman or commissioners shall execute an affidavit, under oath, attesting to the fact than only exempt topics were discussed in the session. (5) Minutes of real estate acquisition, as described in subsection (b)(3) above are required; minutes of other executive sessions may be recorded at the direction of the chairman. (6) Commissioners, officials, employees and other persons who attend executive sessions are prohibited from discussing or in any other way disclosing information, legal advice or legal strategy discussed in the executive session unless: a. The disclosure is required by law; b. The disclosure is a part of a judicial or formal administrative procedure; or c. The majority of the board authorizes the disclosure. (7) Any commissioner, official, or employee that divulges, has previously divulged, or has threatened to divulge information, legal advice, or legal strategy discussed in an executive session may be excluded from participation in executive sessions by majority affirmative vote of the board of commissioners. A commissioner that divulges executive session information may be publicly sanctioned by a majority affirmative vote of the board of commissioners. (Ord. of 6-7-2011(1)) Sec. 2-24. - Conducting meetings. (a) Quorum. A quorum shall be defined as three commissioners excluding the chairman. A quorum shall be present at a meeting to conduct business. (b) Public notice. Public notice of meetings shall be provided in accordance with state law. (c) Schedule of meetings. The commissioners will conduct meetings as follows: (1) Regular monthly meeting will be held as specified in Part 1. Local Acts, Section 7, of the Code of Polk County. (2) Regular work session will be held on the Monday prior to the regular meeting each month at a time and place selected and advertised by the board of commissioners. (3) Called work sessions or special meetings will be held at times and places selected and advertised by the board of commissioners. (4) Committee meetings shall be held at times and places selected by committees with proper notice given. (d) Chair. The chair of the board of commissioners shall serve as presiding officer at all meetings and shall ensure the orderly conduct of meetings. The chair shall vote only in case of a tie vote. (e) Election of chair. The members of the board shall elect, by majority vote, the chair for the year, and the election shall be held at the January meeting. (f) Election of vice-chair. The members of the board shall elect, by majority vote, a vice-chair for the year, and the election shall be held at the January meeting. The vice-chair shall act as the chair for any meeting at which the chair is absent. (g) Rules of order. Unless provided otherwise by local amendment, Robert's Rules of Order shall serve as the guide for conducting all meetings of the commission. (h) Parliamentarian. The county attorney shall serve as the parliamentarian for the commission. (i) Recordings. Persons have the right to video or audio tape all open meetings. (j) Conduct of the public. All persons attending shall conduct themselves in a respectful, appropriate manner. (1) Anyone wishing to speak shall first be recognized by the chair. (2) All comments shall be directed to the chair, and not to individual commissioners or staff. (3) Personal attacks, derogatory comments, or profanities are prohibited. (k) Conduct of the board of commissioners. All commissioners shall conduct themselves in a respectful, appropriate manner. (1) Commissioners desiring to speak shall first be recognized by the chair. (2) Commissioners may only discuss the motion that is being discussed. (3) Personal attacks, inappropriate remarks, personal grievances, or profanities are prohibited. (Ord. of 6-7-2011(1); Ord. of 3-4-2014) Secs. 2-25—2-48. - Reserved. ARTICLE III. - OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY

DIVISION 2. - CODE OF ETHICS[1] Footnotes:
Subdivision I. - In General
Sec. 2-72. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: County official means any person who is an elected county representative. Employee means any person who is a full-time or part-time employee of the county. Government or county means Polk County, Georgia government. Immediate family means the employee or county official, spouse and children of said parties. (Res. of 1-7-2003, art. A, § 1) Sec. 2-73. - Acceptance of gifts. (a) No county official shall solicit or accept directly or indirectly anything of value from any person, corporation, or group which: (1) Has, or is seeking to obtain contractual or other business or financial relationships with the county; (2) In exchange for the thing of value seeks to have a county official exercise a matter of discretion in his favor; (3) In exchange for the thing of value seeks to have interests which may be affected by the performance or nonperformance of the official duty of the county official. (b) This section shall not apply to campaign contributions which shall be reported in accordance with state law. (Res. of 1-7-2003, art. A, § 2) Sec. 2-74. - Intent. It is the intent of this section that county officials avoid any action whether or not specifically prohibited by section 2-73 which might result in, or create the appearance of the following: (1) Using public office for private gain; (2) Impeding government efficiency or economy; (3) Affecting adversely the confidence of the public in the integrity of the government; or (4) Purposefully or intentionally violating laws involving moral turpitude as defined by state law. (Res. of 1-7-2003, art. A, § 3) Sec. 2-75. - Financial interests of members. County officials may not: (1) Have direct or indirect financial interests that conflict substantially with their responsibilities and duties as government servants; or (2) Engage in, directly or indirectly, financial transactions as a result of, or primarily relying upon, information obtained from their office. Aside from these restrictions, county officials are free to engage in lawful financial transactions to the same extent as private citizens. (Res. of 1-7-2003, art. A, § 4) Sec. 2-76. - Use of public property. A county official shall not use county government property of any kind for other than officially approved activities, nor direct employees to use such property for the personal purposes of such official. (Res. of 1-7-2003, art. A, § 5) Sec. 2-77. - Use of confidential information. A county official shall not directly or indirectly, make use of, or permit others to make use of, for the purpose of furthering a private interest, official information not made available to the general public. (Res. of 1-7-2003, art. A, § 6) Sec. 2-78. - Coercion by county official. A county official shall not use his position in any way to coerce, or give the appearance of coercing, another person to provide any financial benefit to him or persons within his immediate family, or those with whom an official has business or financial ties. (Res. of 1-7-2003, art. A, § 7) Sec. 2-79. - Voting in matters of personal interest. A county official shall not vote on an ordinance or amendment in a meeting that would directly affect his private business, business interests or property; nor such interests of his immediate family. (Res. of 1-7-2003, art. A, § 8) Sec. 2-80. - Unauthorized purchases. A county official shall not order any goods and services for the county, nor obligate county funds for any payment, without prior official authorization for such an expenditure. (Res. of 1-7-2003, art. A, § 9) Sec. 2-81. - County attorneys used for private business. A county official shall not use the attorney or attorneys who are under retainer by the county for personal or private business without paying just compensation. (Res. of 1-7-2003, art. A, § 10) Sec. 2-82. - Unauthorized use of public employees. A county official shall not use his superior position to request or require an employee to: (1) Do clerical work on behalf of his family, business, social, church or fraternal interests; (2) Purchase goods and services to be used for personal, business or political purposes; (3) Work for him personally without offering just compensation; (4) Perform work allegedly for the benefit of the county without prior official authorization. (Res. of 1-7-2003, art. A, § 11) Sec. 2-83. - Reserved. Editor's note— Section 2-83 has been superseded by §§ 2-500 et seq. and has been deleted at the direction of the county. The former § 2-83 pertained to travel expenses and derived from Art. A, § 12 of a resolution adopted Jan. 7, 2003. Sec. 2-84. - Penalties. The provisions of this division shall be observed by county officials as set forth above and any violation thereof shall subject the offender to disciplinary action which may include censure and either public or private reprimand. Power to administer a greater punishment shall include power to administer the lesser. (Res. of 1-7-2003, art. A, § 13) Secs. 2-85—2-111. - Reserved. Subdivision II. - Administration
Sec. 2-112. - Ethics committee. The ethics committee shall consist of three persons, one from each commission district, all appointed by the board of commissioners. All members shall be residents of the county and shall serve a two-year term. (Res. of 1-7-2003, art. B, § 1; Ord. No. 2018-06, § 1, 4-3-2018) Sec. 2-113. - Receipt of complaints. (a) All ethics complaints shall be filed in writing with the county manager. The county manager shall present written complaints to the ethics committee in a called meeting within ten days after receiving written complaints. A copy of any filed complaint shall be forwarded to the party against whom the complaint is filed. (b) Upon receipt of a complaint in proper form, the ethics committee shall review it to determine whether the complaint is unjustified, frivolous, patently unfounded or fails to state facts sufficient to invoke the disciplinary jurisdiction for the county board of commissioners. The ethics committee shall be empowered to subpoena parties, collect evidence and information concerning any complaint and to add the findings and results of its investigations to the file containing such complaint. Upon completion of an investigation of a complaint, files shall be maintained by the county clerk. (c) Upon completion of its investigation of a complaint, the ethics committee shall be empowered to dismiss those complaints which are unjustified, frivolous, patently unfounded or which fail to state facts sufficient to invoke the disciplinary jurisdiction of the county board of commissioners; provided, however, that a rejection of such complaint by the ethics committee shall not deprive the complaining party of any action he might otherwise have at law or in equity against the respondent government servant. (d) The ethics committee shall be empowered to conduct probable cause investigations, to take evidence and hold hearings. (e) The ethics committee shall be empowered to adopt forms for formal complaints, subpoenas, notices, applications for reinstatement and any other written instruments necessary or desirable under these rules. (f) Should the committee determine that disciplinary action is warranted, it shall make written findings and recommendations to the county board of commissioners within ten days after concluding their review and investigation of a complaint. (g) The official against whom a complaint is filed may present evidence to the ethics committee and/or county commission concerning any alleged complaints. (Res. of 1-7-2003, art. B, § 2; Ord. No. 2018-06, § 1, 4-3-2018) Sec. 2-114. - Additional regulations. This division shall be cumulative to any other ordinance, resolution or act now existing. (Res. of 1-7-2003, art. B, § 3) Sec. 2-115. - Right to appeal. Any final decision by the county commission pursuant to this division shall be reviewable by the superior court of the county. The review by the superior court shall be limited to an inquiry of whether there was any evidence before the board which supported the decision of the board. Provided, however, no action of the board refusing or failing to take action pursuant to this code of ethics shall be reviewable by the superior court. (Res. of 1-7-2003, art. B, § 4) Sec. 2-116. - Conflict of interest. No elected official, appointed officer, or employee of the county or any agency or political entity to which this division applies shall knowingly engage in any business or transaction or have any financial or other personal interest, direct or indirect, which is incompatible with the proper discharge of his official duties or which would tend to impair his independence of judgment or action in the performance of his official duties. (Res. of 1-7-2003, art. B, § 5) Secs. 2-117—2-145. - Reserved. Subdivision III. - Conflict of Interest and Code of Ethics
Sec. 2-146. - Acceptance of gifts, gratuities, special privileges. (a) Employees and county officials shall not accept any gifts, loans, rewards, favors, or services that may reasonably tend to improperly influence them in the discharge of their official duties. This limitation is not intended to prohibit the acceptance of articles of negligible value which are distributed generally not to prohibit loans from regular lending institutions. It is particularly important that employees and officials guard against relationships which might be constructed as, or give the appearance of: favoritism, coercion, unfair advantage or collusion. (b) Employees shall not use or attempt to use their position to secure an economic benefit or advantages, special privileges or exemptions for themselves or others including the use of knowledge obtained through their employment or by virtue of their position. (c) Employees shall not accept employment or engage in any business or professional activity which they may reasonably expect would require or induce them to disclose confidential information acquired by them by reason of their official position. (Res. of 1-7-2003, art. C, § 1) Sec. 2-147. - Proprietorship of creations. All plans, designs, reports, specifications, drawings, devices, inventions, and other items produced or created by employees during working hours or through the use of county facilities or equipment or at the request of the county shall be and become the sole property of the county. (Res. of 1-7-2003, art. C, § 2) Sec. 2-148. - Confidential information. Employees shall not disclose confidential information gained by reason of their official position, nor shall they otherwise use such information for their personal gain or benefit. (Res. of 1-7-2003, art. C, § 3) Sec. 2-149. - Conflict of interest. (a) If an employee of the county is an officer, director, agent or member of, or owns interest in any entity which is subject to the regulation of, or which has financial commitments with the county, they shall file a sworn statement to this effect with the county clerk. (b) Employees shall not transact any business in their official capacity with any business entity of which he is an officer, director, agent, member, or in which he owns a controlling interest, excluding civic, charitable or religious organizations. (c) Employees shall not have personal investment in any enterprise which will create a conflict or a perceived conflict between their private interest and the public interest. (d) This prohibition shall extend to employees, county officials and their immediate families. (Res. of 1-7-2003, art. C, § 4) Sec. 2-150. - Reserved. Editor's note— Section 2-150 has been superseded by § 2-180 et seq. and has been deleted at the direction of the county. The former § 2-150 pertained to political activity and derived from Art. C, § 5 of a resolution adopted Jan. 7, 2003. Sec. 2-151. - Reserved. Sec. 2-152. - Committee appointments. (a) County commission committees are appointed annually by the chairman of the board of commissioners. These committees may include, but not limited to, the following: (1) Airport. (2) Bid. (3) Finance. (4) Environmental. (5) Intergovernmental. (6) Ordinance. (7) Malt beverage. (8) Personnel. (9) Public safety. (10) Public works. (11) Library board (two members). (c) In order to prevent conflicts of interest and to assure broad public representation, a citizen may serve on only one at a time of the of the boards listed in subsection (b) above. (d) The county commission chair shall serve as an ex-officio member of the commission committees. (Ord. of 6-7-2011(1); Ord. of 6-5-2012(1)) Secs. 2-153—2-168. - Reserved. Secs. 2-169—2-179. - Reserved. DIVISION 3. - PERSONNEL
Sec. 2-180. - Introduction. This division details policies and procedures as adopted by the board of county commissioners. Employees are to contact the department head or county administration with questions. (Ord. of 11-1-2010, § 1) Sec. 2-181. - Authority. The Polk County Board of Commissioners duly adopted the ordinance in this division on June 1, 2004 and amended as of October 9, 2007, May 6, 2008, February 3, 2009, March 2, 2010, November 1, 2010, June 7. 2011, January 10, 2012, July 3, 2012, August 7, 2012, June 4, 2013, September 10, 2013, and May 6, 2014. All policies, procedures and rules in conflict with this division as amended are repealed. Policies within this division may be amended by a majority vote of the board of commissioners. (Ord. of 11-1-2010, § 2; Ord. of 5-6-2014) Sec. 2-182. - Definitions. For the purpose of administering these policies the following words shall have the meaning indicated: Adverse action means a demotion, suspension without pay, or dismissal. Adverse actions may be appealed. Anniversary date means the date on which an employee begins employment and thus the date from which seniority service is determined. Appointed employees means employees placed in their positions by a legislated authority. Appointed employees include all employees appointed by constitutional officers (sheriff, clerk of court, probate judge, and tax commissioner), and the following employees appointed by the board of commissioners: county manager, assistant county manager, county clerk, and county department heads. Day or working day means an eight-hour period of assigned work for an employee working a standard 40-hour work week. Dismissal means disciplinary action against an employee resulting in termination of employment for a violation of policies or for cause. Employee benefits means benefits provided to full time employees, including, but not limited to, annual leave, sick leave, paid holidays, funeral leave, civil duty leave, retirement, and group health insurance. Extended family shall be defined as any kin by blood or marriage including cousins, nieces or nephews. Full-time position means a position authorized by the board of commissioners and the working hours are the normal established hours for the department. For departments which open/operate for eight hours per day, five days per week, a full time position is 40 hours. For departments that operate on a 24/7 basis, established full time position hours may be greater than 40 hours. Furlough means the placement on leave without pay for one or more days. A furlough may be mandatory or may be voluntary with authorization from the board of commissioners. Grade means a pay range for a position or a group of positions of comparable worth. Each grade shall have a minimum pay, a maximum pay, and incremental steps in between. Grievance means a complaint by an employee concerning the interpretation or application of rules, regulations, or departmental operating procedures when he/she believes the misinterpretation or unfair application affects the conditions of his/her work. Immediate family shall be defined as parent, grandparent, child, grandchild, brother, sister, and spouse; and the same relationships to spouse; or any relative domiciled in the employee's home. In-pay status means when an employee is working, or on authorized paid leave. Overtime means time worked beyond established hours and according to provisions of the Fair Labor Standards Act. Part time position means a position authorized for work for less than the normal, established working hours for the department. A person in this position is not eligible for employee benefits, and serves at the pleasure of the department. Position means a job with assigned duties and responsibilities. Regular employee means an employee having successfully completed the initial probationary period and is assigned to a full time position. Step means an increment of pay within a grade. Temporary position means a position authorized for a special project or work of a temporary nature. A person in this position is not eligible for employee benefits. Unpaid leave status means when an employee is either on approved leave and has exhausted available sick and annual leave, or when an employee is on approved leave but would have exhausted available leave had such been claimed in a timely manner. (Ord. of 3-3-2009; Ord. of 11-1-2010, § 3) Sec. 2-183. - General administration. (a) Polk County is an Equal Opportunity Employer and complies with all applicable employment regulations including the Fair Labor Standards Act and the Americans with Disability Act. All policies are carried out without regard to an employee's age, sex, race, color, creed, religion, political affiliation, national origin, disability, or physical handicap. (b) All employees are "at will" employees and subject to termination with or without cause. Employees serve at the pleasure of the county and have no vested rights in his/her employment except as may be provided by a specific contract for individual services. (c) The board of commissioners makes appointments to these positions: county manager, assistant county manager, county clerk, and heads of the following departments: building inspector, 911 director, EMA director, road superintendent, county police chief, and EMS director. The board has the right to make appointments to other positions as appropriate, or to defer the appointment to a committee or staff member. (d) The board of commissioners shall have the right to create a human resources director position separate from the county manager. The human resources director has the authority and responsibility to fairly interpret, apply, and enforce these policies. Until such position is created or if the position is vacant the county manager shall serve as human resources director. (Ord. of 11-1-2010, § 4) Sec. 2-184. - Employment. (a) Recruitment and position vacancies. (1) Vacancies for full time, full time, and temporary positions shall be filled by a competitive process. All recruitment and selection activities shall fully meet federal and state requirements on equal employment. If a position or similar position has been publicly advertised within the preceding 12 months, and ample applications from qualified candidates are on file, then the position need not be re-advertised. (2) A county employee may apply for an open position if qualified; however, applications of qualified candidates from the public are not excluded. In the event a county employee and a public applicant have equal qualifications then the county employee would have preference. A county employee going to a higher graded position would receive a pay increase, and a county employee going to a lower graded position would receive a pay decrease. Pay increases and decreases shall be determined by requirements of the current classification and pay plan. (3) All positions and staffing shall be approved in the annual budget. Additional positions or amended positions in terms of grade and classification require the approval of the board of commissioners. Re-evaluation of position classification shall be determined by requirements of the current classification and pay plan. (4) Application forms, recruitment and selection requirements, and job advertising information will be provided by the commissioners office as may be needed and requested. (5) Applicants may be disqualified for employment for any of the following reasons: a. Does not meet minimum requirements for the job. b. Fraud or deception, or attempt of such, regarding qualifications or work history. c. Felony convictions or under current indictment for a felony. d. Unresolved misdemeanor charges involving moral turpitude. e. Unsatisfactory past record of employment as determined via contact with previous employers or references. f. Failure to keep scheduled interview appointments. g. Positive results on pre-employment drug test. (6) Department heads and supervisors are prohibited from hiring members of their immediate or extended family into positions within their direct line of authority. (7) Immediate family members of the following employees and officials are ineligible for employment with the county: county commissioners, the county manager, assistant county manager, and county clerk. (8) Members of the same immediate family shall not be employed in the same department. (9) In very unusual or hardship circumstances, the board of commissioners may be petitioned for relief of these requirements. (b) New employee orientation. (1) All new, full time employees are required to attend the first available orientation class so as to be familiar with policies, procedures, requirements, rights and benefits. Part time employees are encouraged to attend. (Ord. of 11-1-2010, § 5; Ord. of 7-3-2012) Sec. 2-185. - Probationary status. (a) Initial probationary status shall be, at a minimum, the initial six months after being hired or rehired by Polk County. If at the end of the initial six months the employee's job performance is satisfactory, the employee shall be placed in regular status. The initial probationary period may be extended for an additional six months should performance not meet complete expectations. (b) Promotional probationary status shall be the first six months after a county employee is promoted to a position in a higher grade. This period may not be extended and failure to perform satisfactorily shall result in demotion to a lower grade. (Ord. of 11-1-2010, § 6) Sec. 2-186. - Jobs, wages, and increases. (a) Position and classification. The employee position and pay classification plan used by the county shall be the plan designed by the University of Georgia and amended by the board of commissioners. The intent of the plan is to provide accurate job descriptions, equitable pay grades for jobs of equitable worth, minimum starting pay for all positions, maximum pay for all positions, and provisions for longevity, education, and certain certifications. (1) New employees may be placed in the plan on the grade designated for the position plus additional steps determined as follows: Step increases for past job related experience may be given to new employees at the rate of one step for each year of prior job related experience up to five years. (2) Advanced education shall be defined as being awarded a formal degree through an accredited college or university. A two step increase shall be awarded for an Associate's Degree (two year degree) or a four step increase for a Bachelor's Degree (two steps if the employee had previously been awarded one two steps for an Associate's Degree). The validity of a degree obtained through the internet shall be determined by the commissioner's office. (3) Employees that are promoted from within, shall receive a pay increase based upon the following: Two lateral step increases shall be given for each increase in grade. The employee shall be placed in the new grade at the resulting hourly wage. If the new wage is less than the starting pay for the new grade, the employee shall be paid the starting pay for the new grade. (b) Wages and increases. (1) Wage rates shall be maintained for all grades and steps via the classification and pay plan as amended by the board of commissioners. a. Hourly rates are provided for all employees eligible for overtime in accordance with the Fair Labor Standards Act. b. Salary rate is per annum pay divided into equal installments. Hours of work shall be the general hours of the department. Non paid leave hours shall be deducted from the salary rate, and work hours required beyond the normal working hours may be compensated in time at a later period. Additional pay for hours beyond the normal working hours is not authorized for salary rate employees. c. Other rates may be established by the board of commissioners. d. Employees shall be granted an appropriate increase in pay for promotion to a job with a higher-grade classification. e. Employees may be given other pay increases as granted by the board of commissioners. f. The finance committee shall review and approve all change of status requests when such changes would create a new position, cause an increase in an employee's salary, and/or a department's budget for regular and overtime salaries, outside of board approved increases and increases authorized by this division. (c) Status. (1) Initial probationary status is, at the minimum, the initial six months of employment; and for cause, can be extended for a period up to six additional months. (2) Regular status is the permanent status for full time employees satisfactorily performing their duties. (3) Promotional probationary status is the initial six months following a promotion to a position of higher classification. At the end of the six months the employee is either classified to regular status in the higher position or returned to a lower classified position. (d) Overtime. Overtime is time required to work beyond normal weekly work assignments or as defined by the Fair Labor Standards Act. The county complies with all legal requirements regarding employment. Except for public safety employees hours beyond 80 hours bi-weekly shall be considered overtime. Additionally the following applies: (1) Overtime or extra hours of work shall be authorized in advance by the department head or appropriate supervisor. (2) Employees are prohibited from generating their own overtime. Early "punch in" or late "punch out" to create overtime is prohibited. (3) Travel time to and from work shall not count. (4) Only hours actually worked may be counted for purposes of overtime. Paid leave, jury duty, etc., shall not count toward overtime. (5) Some positions may be exempt by law from overtime eligibility. (e) Performance evaluations. (1) The purpose of a job evaluation is to recognize performance, to identify areas in work which need improvement, and as appropriate, to establish specific requirements for continued employment. Constitutional officers shall determine appropriate performance evaluations for their staff members and the board of commissioners shall determine such for their employees. Any necessary forms shall be provided by the board of commissioners. a. Performance evaluations are required at a minimum: 1. At the end of the initial probationary period of employment. Typically six months. 2. At the end of a promotional probationary period. Typically six months. 3. At the end of each year of service on the employee's anniversary date of hire. b. Each full-time employee of Polk County will have a written annual job performance evaluation which will be conducted by the employee's immediate supervisor. The written evaluation will take place on, or within a few days of, the employee's anniversary date of hire. Based on the employee's evaluation, the next evaluation could be scheduled earlier than the next service anniversary date when performance deficiencies are noted. Job performance evaluations are scheduled at the discretion of each supervisor, but not less than once per year at a minimum. (f) Comp time . (1) Compensatory time (comp time) is paid time off in lieu of payment for hours worked over and above the regular hours established for a position. The purpose of this policy is to establish authorized compensatory time accrual, use and limitations. This policy does not create any contractual rights. The county reserves the right to, at any time, amend, revise or terminate the policy. (2) Department heads shall be eligible for comp time. Other key or senior staff may, at the discretion of the county manager, be granted temporary comp time eligibility in appropriate situations. Nonexempt employees shall be eligible for comp time if voluntarily agreed to and documented in a signed agreement. The rate of accrual shall be one and one-half times the work time required over and above regular established hours. (3) Department heads and senior staff are expected to organize their work appropriately so as to minimize comp time accrual. In county work hours necessarily performed over and above normal work hours shall be accrued for comp time. Such work hours shall be clearly required or be of an emergency nature, and staff cannot voluntarily work just to create their own comp time. (4) Out of county work hours shall be defined as required travel time (beyond a normal work day) and actual time attending class or meetings (beyond a normal work day), and shall be eligible for comp time providing the out of county meeting or conference was required as part of the employee's job. Not eligible for comp time are all times spent in leisure activities, dining, and sleeping. (5) Staff shall use accrued comp time in a way so as to not disrupt normal departmental functions or create hardships on other employees. Staff are encouraged to use comp time in a manner similar to how it was accrued, i.e., a few hours at a time. (6) At any given time an employee shall not have more than 30 hours banked in accrued comp time. (7) At the end of each month a department head shall electronically submit to the county clerk and the county manager a copy of their comp time log reflecting data on accrual and utilization of comp time. (8) In no case shall accrued comp time be paid as wages to an employee instead of the employee taking time off. (9) Employees shall keep a log detailing dates, hours, and reasons for the accrual and when the time was taken. At a minimum, the employee's comp time log shall reflect the following:
The reason would be the reason comp time was necessarily generated, or in the case of using comp time, the reason would simply list using comp time. (10) The following actions are prohibited, this listing is not meant to be exhaustive: a. Falsifying hours earned or worked. b. Generating comp time via early starts or late quits when such is neither necessary nor required. c. Claiming comp time for work performed at home. d. Violations of the comp time policy. (11) The county manager shall be authorized to have discretion in appropriate cases to temporarily suspend an employee's comp time privileges. The employee would have the right to initiate action to appeal the temporary suspension. (12) Violations of the comp time policy shall result in disciplinary action, up to and including termination. (Ord. of 11-1-2010, § 7; Ord. of 12-4-2012(1); Ord. of 6-4-2013(1); Ord. of 7-3-2012; Ord. of 5-6-2014; Ord. No. 2018-10, § 1, 6-5-2018) Sec. 2-187. - Employee standards. (a) Employees shall carry out their duties in a manner to not discredit themselves or Polk County. Employees having contact with the public shall be courteous and professional in manner, speaking, and attitude. (b) Employees shall conform to the county code of ethics. (c) Employees shall dress in a neat, professional manner appropriate for their positions, and if uniforms are provided, the proper uniform shall be worn. (d) Employees shall not conduct personal business while on duty. (e) Employees shall report for duty on time and shall avoid "late starts" and "early quits." (f) Employees are prohibited from soliciting personal loans from other employees or County officials. (g) Employees shall not abuse leave. (h) Employees are solely responsible for punching their own time card. Employees are prohibited from punching the time card of another employee. (Ord. of 11-1-2010, § 8) Sec. 2-188. - Seniority. (a) Seniority is the amount of full time service with the county. In the event of lay-offs or promotions, seniority may be the determining factor if all other factors are equal. (1) Part time, seasonal, or temporary service shall not count for seniority compilation. (2) An employee who is rehired after a previous stint of employment with the county will be eligible to regain his/her previous service in terms of seniority under the following guide: a. The employee must have resigned the previous employment in good standing. b. After two years of employment the previous service shall be credited for seniority purposes. (3) An existing county employee returning to a department he/she previously worked in shall maintain his/her seniority with the county, but not any seniority previously earned in the department. (4) An employee who is rehired after a previous stint of employment, of at least ten years with the county, may be eligible for credit for past experience with the county, of up to a maximum of 15 years, based upon beginning at starting pay. Step increases for past experience with the county shall be allowed at the rate of one step for every year of past experience. The following requirements shall also apply: a. The employee must be rehired into the same department and position as before. b. The employee shall be eligible for experience credit if returning after one year but not more than five years from the date of separation from the county. c. The employee's returning salary shall not exceed his/her previous salary. d. The department's overall budget and budget for salaries shall not be exceeded due to the rehire. e. The employee shall be under a six month probationary period after returning. f. During the employee's absence, employee must have been employed in a similar field as the position they are returning to. (Ord. of 11-1-2010, § 9; Ord. of 5-6-2014) Sec. 2-189. - Political activity. (a) Employee rights. Employees, except as noted elsewhere in this section, have the right to vote as he/she pleases, privately express opinions on political subjects, or maintain political neutrality; join political parties and attend political functions; make voluntary contributions to candidates and causes; and take part in political campaigns during off duty time. (b) Public visibility positions. Due to high public visibility and/or certain responsibilities with elections, persons in the following positions shall be required to maintain political neutrality and are prohibited form taking, even off duty, an active role in a political campaign: county manager; assistant county manager; county clerk; members, board of elections staff; board of elections. (c) Prohibited political activities. (1) Employees shall be prohibited from engaging in any political activity while on duty. (2) Employees shall not use their county positions for political purposes or for influencing the vote of any person. (3) Employees shall not engage in political activity or attend political functions while in a county uniform. (4) Employees shall not use a county vehicle or county equipment for any political purpose or while performing political activities. (5) Employees and officials are prohibited from soliciting employees for political contributions. (d) Employee seeking/holding public office. (1) A person is prohibited from being a county employee and holding a county elective position at the same time. A person may be a county employee and hold an elective office not part of county government. (2) An employee seeking an elective office has the right to either take unpaid leave or paid annual leave during the campaign, or the employee, except as noted below, may continue to work providing the employee complies fully with all terms of this ordinance. (3) Due to high visibility and certain responsibilities during elections, persons in the following positions shall be required to take a leave of absence upon qualifying for an elected position: county manager, assistant county manager, county clerk, member of the board of elections, and staff for the board of elections. (Ord. of 11-1-2010, § 10) Sec. 2-190. - Outside employment. Employees shall not engage in outside employment or businesses which conflict with county responsibilities. Outside employment plans shall be reported to the department head, who in turn, shall report to the county manager for outside employment clearance. Full time employees shall not have outside full time employment. Employees may not have vested or financial interest in any vendor, company, or service doing business with the county without the formal approval of the board of commissioners. (Ord. of 11-1-2010, § 11) Sec. 2-191. - Internet, telephones, and social media. (a) Employees may use the Internet for county business or for research in the performance of their duties as authorized by a department head. (b) Employees shall not use county computers or county communication devices for the purpose of any illegal, fraudulent, or malicious activity; nor for viewing, sending, receiving, or using data which is profane or offensive to a reasonable person. (c) Employees are prohibited from using county computers or county telecommunication devices for any political, religious, or personal activity. (d) Employees are prohibited from playing games on county computers or communication devices (whether personal or county owned) while on duty. (e) Employees are prohibited from engaging in personal social media exchanges (such as Facebook, Twitter, YouTube, etc.) while on duty. (f) Employees are expected to be mindful and cautious in their use of social media in their private lives so as to not undermine the functions of county government. (g) Employees are prohibited from texting or making personal telephone calls while on duty except in cases of emergency. Employees may use break and lunch periods for personal communications. (h) Employees provided with county cell phones shall use such for county business purposes only. Personal charges or overages due to personal use shall be the responsibility of the employee. (i) Employees are prohibited from using cell phones or cell phone type devices while operating county vehicles or equipment; and employees are prohibited from using such devices whole operating personal vehicles while on county business. (j) Employees violating policies in this section shall be subject to disciplinary action. (Ord. of 11-1-2010, § 12; Ord. of 7-3-2012) Sec. 2-192. - County vehicles and equipment. (a) Employees/volunteers driving county vehicles shall have a valid driver's license appropriate for the class of the county vehicle. Loss of license shall be reported to the department head immediately. The county will check the validity of licenses on an annual basis. (b) Employees/volunteers driving county vehicles shall adhere to all state laws and local ordinances applicable to driving a vehicle. Fines levied for failure to follow such laws and ordinances shall be the sole burden of the employee driving the vehicle. When an employee or volunteer is deemed by legal authority to be at fault in either an accident while operating a county vehicle/equipment or incident resulting to damage to county property then the employee/volunteer shall be subject to paying up to $300.00 toward the deductible/repair in addition to other disciplinary actions. (c) Employees/volunteers shall not abuse vehicles and shall follow all established or recommended operating procedures, including obtaining regular maintenance, for the vehicle. (d) County vehicles, county equipment, and county property shall only be used for county business in the performance of duties with the following exception. County police officers shall be allowed to use their vehicles while working off duty security type jobs, provided they reimburse the county for the use of such vehicles at the rate of $4.00 per hour. (e) Employees permitted to take a county vehicle home shall take a direct route to and from work and shall not make personal use of the vehicle while off duty. Additional requirements may be established by departmental procedures. (f) All persons operating or riding in a county vehicle shall wear a seat belt while the vehicle is in operation. (g) All persons operating or riding in a rental or personal vehicle on county business shall wear seat belts when the vehicle is in operation. (h) All employees shall use seatbelts on all mobile equipment that is equipped with seatbelts and a rollover protection device. (i) Department heads shall provide and document annual training on the required use of seatbelts for their departmental employees. (Ord. of 11-1-2010, § 13; Ord. of 6-7-2011(2); Ord. of 6-4-2013(2)) Sec. 2-193. - Sexual harassment. (a) Sexual harassment or harassment of any form is prohibited and shall not be tolerated. Persons with a harassment complaint need not follow the formal grievance procedure. Persons with a harassment complaint should immediately report such to either the department head, the county clerk, or the county manager. (1) The following behaviors which exemplify sexual harassment are prohibited: a. Kidding or joking about sex, directly or indirectly. b. Hugs, pats, or any type of physical contact (other than handshakes). c. Posting or passing around cartoons, photos, or jokes referring to sex. d. Use of vulgar or offensive language. e. Use of flirtatious behavior or language. f. Verbal/written unwanted solicitation for dates. g. Offers of employment/promotion in exchange for sexual favors. h. Behavior that is perceived as offensive or sexual in nature. (2) The following behaviors which exemplify harassment are prohibited: a. Behavior which is perceived as intimidating or threatening. b. Badgering or verbal abuse. c. Use of vulgar, offensive language or obscene gestures. d. Hitting, shoving, excessive teasing or "horseplay." (Ord. of 11-1-2010, § 14) Sec. 2-194. - Substance abuse. (a) The county strongly believes in policies and requirements prohibiting abuse of drugs and alcohol so as to promote a safe environment for employees and the community. All employees/volunteers shall comply with federal, state and local ordinances in addition to this policy regarding the abuse of drugs and alcohol. Employees are encouraged to voluntarily seek professional help with alcohol or substance abuse issues. (b) The county's substance abuse policy for employees/volunteers includes the following components: (1) Pre-employment testing. (2) Random testing for safety-sensitive employees/volunteers. (3) Post accident testing. (4) Return to duty testing. (5) Reasonable cause testing. [3] (c) Refusal to submit to a drug or alcohol test, or tampering with any test required by this policy shall be result in termination. (d) An employee receiving a first positive result in a drug or alcohol test shall be immediately placed on leave without pay and be given the choice of termination or seeking treatment. An employee agreeing to seek treatment shall enroll in an appropriate treatment program within five days after being given notice of the positive. Failure to enroll within the five-day window shall result in termination. Determination on whether or not the planned treatment program is appropriate and acceptable shall be made by the governing authority. Failure to satisfactorily complete the treatment program shall result in termination. Time off from work for treatment may be a combination of sick leave, vacation, or unpaid leave. (e) Any employee with a history of substance or alcohol abuse shall be included in the random test pool. Any employee with a substance or alcohol related misdemeanor conviction, shall be included in the random test pool. (f) Any employee with a felony drug conviction shall be terminated. Applicants with a felony drug conviction shall be ineligible for employment. (g) The random pool shall consist of all public safety employees, all employees deemed safety sensitive by federal or state guidelines, and employees so designated by this section. (h) State or federal requirements regarding alcohol/substance use which are more restrictive than this division shall take precedence over county policies. (i) A second positive test, at any time, shall result in termination. (Ord. of 11-1-2010, § 15) Footnotes: --- (3) --- Any employee/volunteer exhibiting signs, symptoms of substance abuse or if there is evidence indicating abuse or other forms of reasonable cause then a department head may require immediate testing.
Sec. 2-195. - Departmental operating procedures. Departments are authorized to establish standard operating procedures for daily operations. Such procedures serve as a supplement to the personnel ordinance and shall not take precedence over policies within the ordinance. (Ord. of 11-1-2010, § 16) Sec. 2-196. - Disciplinary action. (a) Reasons for disciplinary action. (1) Listed below are some, but not all, offenses and reasons for disciplinary action: a. Being convicted of a felony or being convicted of a misdemeanor involving moral turpitude. b. Excessive tardiness or abusing sick or other types of leave. c. Inefficiency, negligence or incompetence in job performance. d. Careless or improper use of county equipment or vehicles. e. Receiving traffic violations or causing accidents while driving county vehicles. f. Giving false statements to supervisors, officials, or the public. g. Being under the influence of drugs or alcohol while on duty. h. Gambling on duty or stealing county property. i. Harassment. j. Participating in work stoppages or slow downs. k. Insubordination or refusing to carry out work directives. l. Violating department operating procedures or county policies. m. Punching another employee's time card. n. Soliciting personal loans from other employees or officials. o. Using county computers for personal business, religious or political activity, illegal activity; or for viewing, sending, or receiving profane or offensive materials. p. Using county cell phones for personal calls or business. q. Using personal cell phones while on duty except during lunch or approved breaks. r. Using a cell phone while operating a county vehicle. (b) Disciplinary action. (1) Disciplinary action is taken in order to correct undesired behavior or performance. In administering disciplinary action, "punishment should fit the crime" rule shall prevail. In all cases violations and disciplinary action shall be well documented. The following types of disciplinary action may be used. a. Verbal warnings. Given to correct minor concerns so as to improve job performance. b. Written reprimand. Given when verbal warnings have not produced results or when a violation demands stronger action than a verbal warning. A written notice detailing the violation and required correction action shall go to the employee with a copy to the commissioners office. c. Demotion with reduction in pay (may be permanent or temporary). An employee failing to satisfactorily perform at a position may be demoted to a lower classified position. The employee shall be provided written notice detailing the violation and required corrective action with a copy to the commissioners office. d. Suspension with pay. May be used in very rare cases, usually for investigative purposes, and requires the approval of the board of commissioners. The employee shall be provided a written notice detailing the conditions of the suspension with a copy to the commissioners office. e. Suspension without pay. An employee may be suspended for up to ten working days for a violation when written reprimands have failed to produce the desired results or when the violation demands stronger action than a written warning. The employee shall be provided written notice detailing the violation and required corrective action with a copy to the commissioners office. f. Written reprimands, demotions, or suspensions without pay may carry an additional period of probation whereby a violation of any type would result in more severe disciplinary action. g. Dismissal. An employee faces dismissal when written reprimands or suspensions have not been effective in correcting unsatisfactory performance or when a violation demands immediate termination. In cases involving dismissal the employee shall be provided a written notice detailing the reasons for the dismissal. A written copy of the dismissal notice shall be provided at once to the commissioners office. h. Written notice. In cases of disciplinary action requiring written notice the employee shall be asked to sign a notation of receipt of the written notice. If the employee refuses the supervisor/department head shall document the refusal. (c) Rights of appeal. (1) Employees have the right to appeal disciplinary action except for verbal warnings, which cannot be appealed. Steps are: a. Notify the county manager of intent to appeal within ten working days of receiving the disciplinary action. The appeal shall be in writing. b. The county manager will schedule a hearing before the personnel committee at the next scheduled personnel committee meeting or within 30 days, whichever occurs first. At the hearing the employee may be represented and provide evidence. c.
