After the hearing a decision will be made and a written decision shall be provided to the employee within ten working days following the personnel committee meeting hearing. d. The decision of the personnel committee shall be final. e. All department head positions are approved by a majority vote of the board of commissioners. Therefore, all department heads have a right of appeal for any disciplinary actions they receive directly to the board of commissioners. Items (c) (1) a. b. c. apply to the department head rights of appeal. Item d. does not. f. In some situations employees of constitutional officers may have hearings before the county attorney. (Ord. of 3-3-2009; Ord. of 11-1-2010, § 17; Ord. No. 2018-07, § 1, 5-8-2018) Sec. 2-197. - Grievance procedure. (a) Every effort should be made by department heads to respond to instances where employees feel they have been treated unfairly. In the rare cases where grievances require formal review the following procedure shall apply. (1) Definition. A grievance is defined as a complaint concerning the interpretation of rules, regulations, procedures or other actions affecting employment. (2) An employee shall not be retaliated against for filing grievance provided the employee is acting in good faith. (3) A grievance shall be first discussed with the department head. (4) If the department head's review/action is not to the employee's satisfaction, then the employee may file the grievance with the county manager within 30 days of the department head giving notice of his/her decision. The grievance to the county manager shall be made in writing. The county manager will meet with the employee and after a review of the issue provide a decision to the employee within ten working days unless there are valid reasons for a required lengthier review. (5) If the county manager's decision is not satisfactory to the employee, a final appeal may be made to the personnel committee. The employee shall notify the county manager in writing within five working days upon receipt of the manager's decision of the intent to have a hearing before the personnel committee. The personnel committee will conduct a hearing within ten working days. The decision of the personnel committee shall be final. (6) All department heads shall have a right to appeal a grievance, on their own behalf, to the board of commissioners. (Ord. of 11-1-2010, § 18; Ord. No. 2018-07, § 1, 5-8-2018) Sec. 2-198. - Transfers and rehires. (a) Lateral transfers shall be approved by the county manager when the employee and both department heads agree. In some circumstances the county manager, with approval of the board of commissioners, may order a transfer without the permission of the employee or department heads. (b) An employee leaving in good standing shall be eligible for one rehire. Employees who have left full time county employment more than one time shall be eligible for additional rehires only with the approval of the county manager. (Ord. of 11-1-2010, § 19; Ord. of 11-3-2015(1)) Sec. 2-199. - Demotion. A demotion, or reduction in job grade with corresponding reduction in pay, may be made for unacceptable job performance or disciplinary action. The demotion may be temporary, conditional, or permanent. (Ord. of 11-1-2010, § 20) Sec. 2-200. - Separations. (a) Resignation. An employee shall provide a 14-day notice of intent to resign. Verbal notices shall be documented by the supervisor. Failure to provide the 14-day notice shall result in loss of re-employment rights. (b) Abandonment. An employee is automatically terminated for "abandonment" if the employee either fails to report for duty for three consecutive days or is absent from work for three consecutive days without notifying the supervisor. (c) Lay off. A layoff is an involuntary separation, not involving disciplinary action or poor performance, when a reduction in personnel becomes necessary. Seniority and critical skills are determining factors, which will be considered by the governing authority should a layoff become necessary. (d) Loss of job requirements. An employee shall be automatically terminated if a necessary, required license or certificate is lost or becomes invalid. (e) Dismissal. Employees may be dismissed for violations of the county code of ethics, for violations of the personnel ordinance, for violations of departmental operating procedures, or for failure to perform the job satisfactorily (f) Retirement. Full retirement for employees shall occur at age 60 with 20 or more years of service. Retiring employees meeting full retirement shall be eligible to continue health benefits by paying the employee portion of cost. Employees with five or more years of service may be eligible for a reduced retirement benefit paid in accordance with the retirement plan. (Ord. of 11-1-2010, § 21) Sec. 2-201. - Holidays and leave. (a) Holidays. (1) The following are currently recognized county holidays and full time employees shall be given a paid working day off: New Years Day, MLK Birthday, Spring Holiday, Memorial Day, July 4th, Labor Day, Veterans Day, Thanksgiving Day and Friday, Christmas Eve and Day. (2) The above days falling on Saturday shall be observed on Friday; falling on Sunday shall be observed on Monday. Employees absent without approved paid leave on a working day before or working day after a holiday shall not receive holiday pay. (3) Employees necessarily working a holiday or employees having the holiday fall on a normal off day shall have the holiday hours added to their accrued vacation time in lieu of the holiday. Such hours shall be added only after the holiday actually occurs. Such hours may only be used as other vacation hours. Holiday pay cannot be claimed as bonus pay. (4) Holiday paid hours shall not apply toward overtime requirements. (5) Part time, temporary, per diem, contract, intermittent or seasonal employees are not eligible for a paid holiday. (6) Only full time employees in in-pay status are eligible for a paid holiday. (b) Annual leave. (1) New employees shall accrue annual leave on a monthly basis at a rate of 6.7 hours per month for the first year. After one year's service a new employee shall be granted the balance of 80 hours less what has been already prorated during that calendar year. (2) Annual leave is granted as follows on January 1 for years of service completed on that date. a. One—five years, per year ..... 80 hours b. Six—12 years, per year ..... 120 hours c. 13—19 years, per year ..... 144 hours d. 20—24 years, per year ..... 160 hours e. 25—29 years, per year ..... 176 hours f. 30 years and up, per year ..... 200 hours (3) Only 80 hours may be carried forward on December 31 to the next year. It shall be the employee's and the department head's responsibility to make certain the employee takes time off before the end of the year. (4) Annual leave may only be claimed for actual hours taken off during a normal work period and may only be claimed for time off of 30 minutes or greater. (5) Annual leave cannot be used to increase the number of hours to be paid within a normal work period above the number of hours normally assigned. (6) Annual leave shall not be used as bonus pay except at the time of separation from county service. Employees separating from service shall be paid for all unused annual leave. (7) Annual leave hours shall not apply toward overtime calculations. (8) Employees shall provide as much notice as possible to the department head when planning annual leave. Department heads shall make every effort to accommodate leave requests from employees, but in some cases inadequate notice may result in the employee being denied leave as requested. (9) Part time, per diem, seasonal, contract, temporary, intermittent or seasonal employees are not eligible to earn or accrue annual leave. (10) Persons in an unpaid status shall not accrue annual leave, but shall regain accrual upon return to duty. (11) Employees may donate annual leave to other employees when such leave is clearly for compassionate or hardship reasons. Written requests shall be made to the county manager who shall make a decision regarding each request. If approved, the leave shall be converted in a manner to equalize the dollars/hours. Furthermore, employees shall only be allowed to donate up to a maximum of one half of their annual leave hours as long as they maintain a minimum balance of 40 hours in their annual leave account. Falsifying reasons for donating leave or selling leave shall be grounds for termination. (c) Sick leave. (1) All regular employees in full time positions shall earn eight hours of sick leave each month provided they are in-pay status for a minimum of 20 calendar days that month. (2) Part time, per diem, temporary, contract, intermittent, or seasonal employees are not eligible for sick leave accrual. (3) Employees in any non-pay status shall not earn sick leave. (4) Sick leave may only be claimed for hours actually missed during a normal work period, and cannot be used to increase the number of hours paid above the hours normally assigned during a work period; and leave may only be claimed for periods of 30 minutes or greater. (5) Sick leave is not a right, but a privilege granted by the board of commissioners, which may be used under the following situations: a. Personal sickness, injury, disability, or required medical and dental treatments or examinations. b. Sickness of an immediate family member (as defined by this division). c. Situation where the employee has been exposed to a serious contagious disease and working may place the health of others at risk. (6) Notification of the desire to take sick leave shall be made to the supervisor prior to the absence when possible, but not longer than 30 minutes after the beginning of the scheduled work period, or as dictated by departmental policy. (7) It shall be the responsibility of the employee to maintain sufficient contact with the department head to make certain the department head is aware of ongoing sick leave and the anticipated date of return to duty. Absences of three or more consecutive days without contact with the supervisor shall be considered job abandonment. (8) Physician's certificate of illness is required when an employee has been absent for longer than three consecutive days. Such certificate may be required for an absence of any length when an employee has established a pattern of excessive absences or when there is evidence the leave is being abused. (9) A physician's certificate is required to qualify the employee as being fit to return to duty when an employee has been hospitalized for any period of time, or has been on FMLA, or has been on workmen's comp leave, or upon any occasion when a department head believes there is a bona fide question of the employee's fitness for duty. (10) Employees may receive compensation for unused sick leave as follows: a. Resignation in good standing or retirement in good standing with less than 20 years of service or under age 60 shall be paid for one-half of unused sick leave. b. Retirement at age 60 or older and with 20 or more years of service shall be paid for all of unused sick leave. c. Involuntary separation in good standing due to disability shall be paid one-half of unused sick leave. d. Other circumstances as may be determined by the board of commissioners. (11) Employees will not receive any compensation for unused sick leave when the separation is due to any type of disciplinary action, poor job performance, job abandonment, on initial probation or at the end of the initial probationary period, loss of necessary license or certification, layoffs, or cases when the employee is "allowed to resign" under unfavorable circumstances rather than face disciplinary action, or other circumstances as determined by the board of commissioners. (12) At the end of a calendar year, all accrued sick leave over 60 days shall be banked into a special account for the employee. As the employee approaches retirement the employee's banked hours shall be applied to the employee's accrued service total. The employee's starting date will be changed to reflect the additional service, and the revised starting date will be submitted for retirement purposes. (13) Employees may donate sick leave to other employees when such leave is clearly for compassionate or hardship reasons. Written requests shall be made to the county manager who shall make a decision regarding each request. If approved, the leave shall be converted in a manner to equalize the dollars/hours. Furthermore, employees shall only be allowed to donate up to a maximum of one-half of their sick leave hours as long as they maintain a minimum balance of 40 hours in their sick leave account. Falsifying reasons for donating leave or selling leave shall be grounds for termination. (d) Family Medical Leave Act. (1) Full time employees in regular status are eligible for leave under the Family Medical Leave Act (FMLA) of 1993. Employees are entitled to up to 12 weeks of leave in any 12-month period. Such 12 weeks may be a combination of both unpaid and paid leave, and such 12 weeks is an accumulative total over any 12-month period. Generally, the leave is granted: a. To care for an employee's child after birth or after placement for adoption or foster care. b. To care for the employee's spouse, child, or parent who has a serious health condition. c. To an employee with a serious health condition making the employee unable to perform his/her job. (2) County administrative office will provide more information including making available a copy of the law to any employee upon request. Applications for FMLA shall be made to the county administration office. (e) Military leave. (1) A full time employee serving in a National Guard or Reserve Unit called to active military service shall be placed on unpaid leave status. Upon completion of active service the county shall comply with federal and state requirements regarding the employee's return to duty. (2) In order to qualify for return to duty the employee must be available for work within 45 days from the date released from full time military duty and the military service must have been honorable in nature. (3) Full time employees serving in the National Guard or military reserves shall have rights granted by law including absences up to 30 days annually (not charged against annual leave) for training camps. Employees must present copies of orders, and upon completion of training, may present copies of pay vouchers and the county will pay a supplement in an amount so as to provide the employee a normal pay level during the training camp. (f) Civil duty leave. (1) Full time employees shall be granted paid leave, not charged to annual leave, for time served when subpoenaed for jury duty. On days when an employee is dismissed from jury duty at or before noon, the employee shall report for his/her county work after lunch. On days when an employee reports back to jury duty after lunch and then is dismissed, the employee shall not have to report for work. (2) A full time employee subpoenaed as a witness shall be granted paid leave, not charged to annual leave, for time serving as a witness, providing such service is on behalf of Polk County or a component of county job duties. Upon completion of subpoenaed duties the employee shall report for regular county work. (3) Failure to comply with terms of this section shall result in the employee not receiving any paid compensation for civil duty leave. (g) Funeral leave. (1) Leave with pay, up to a maximum of three working days, may be granted by a department head for a full time employee when the employee has a death in his/her immediate family. For this provision, immediate family is defined as parent, grandparent, child, grandchild, brother, sister, and spouse; and the same relationships to spouse; or any relative domiciled in the employee's home. (2) Leave with pay, up to a maximum of two hours, may be granted by a department head for a full time employee to attend funerals of friends and other relatives. (h) Leave without pay—General conditions. (1) Employees may be placed on general leave without pay status for a variety of reasons, including, but not limited to: a. An employee seeking public office. b. Personal issues, require board approval. c. Disciplinary reasons. d. Illness or injury beyond FMLA's 12 weeks (requires board approval). e. Furloughs. f. Lay-offs. (2) Employees placed in this status shall neither earn/accrue any type of leave nor be paid for holidays. Employees may maintain their health insurance by continuing to pay the employee portion of the premium. Such payments must be made on schedule. (3) Employees failing to return at a designated time shall be subject to termination; employees in this status accepting employment elsewhere shall be terminated. (4) The maximum length of time an employee shall be in leave without pay status, for reasons other than a serious illness or injury, is 12 weeks during any 12-month period. (5) Furlough is placement on leave without pay for one or more days. A furlough may be mandatory or authorized voluntary. (6) Lay-off is placement on leave without pay for a period of weeks or months. A lay-off may become a permanent separation. (i) Leave without pay—Workers compensation. Employees injured on the job are covered by workers compensation insurance and will be provided appropriate medical care. The workers compensation carrier is responsibility for all workers compensation decisions on treatment and return to work. Additionally, the following govern job related injuries and absences from work due to such injuries: (1) Reporting injuries. An employee is required to immediately report an on the job injury to the supervisor or department head. A "first report of injury" must be filed with the county clerk as soon as possible. (2) Medical care. Except for immediate, emergency care an employee shall obtain treatment from only an authorized physician listed on the county's panel of physicians. A listing of the panel physicians is posted on bulletin boards and is available from the commissioners office. (3) Workers compensation leave without pay. Employees injured on the job and unable to work as determined by appropriate medical physicians shall be placed on workers compensation leave without pay status for a period of time to not exceed one calendar year from the date of injury. The county will hold the employee's position while in this status provided there is reasonable cause to believe the employee will return to duty. While in this status the employee shall not earn leave nor receive holiday pay. An employee in this status may continue health insurance by paying the employee's portion of the premium in a timely manner. After one year's absence the employee shall be placed in workers compensation leave without pay - extended status. a. Return to duty. An employee returning to full time duty from this status shall regain seniority without penalty, and if the county was not able to hold the employee's position, then the most comparable position available will be provided. (4) Workers compensation leave without pay - extended status. Employees determined by appropriate medical physicians to be unable to return to work after one year's absence shall then be placed on workers compensation leave without pay - extended status. An employee shall remain in this status until he/she returns to duty or until a settlement is made. The county will not hold a position for a person in this status. While in this status a person will not earn nor accrue any leave and will not be paid for holidays. While in this status a person may continue health insurance, but only under COBRA. a. Return to duty. An employee returning to full time duty from this status shall regain seniority without penalty, and shall be offered the first available position comparable to the employee's former position. (j) Leave without pay — Disability conditions (other than Workers Comp and FMLA) (1) Employees may request in writing to the Human Resources Department up to 40 weeks of leave without pay, in addition to 12 weeks of family medical leave, for treatment of serious injuries and/or illnesses that prevent an employee from performing the full duties and obligations of their position. In considering such requests, the employee shall provide the human resources department with documentation from a doctor directly responsible for treating a serious injury or illness stating that the employee is expected to be released for full duty at the conclusion of the granted leave. The employee's department head shall also provide a statement explaining the impact the employee's absence will have on the county's operations and budget. Employees meeting the criteria (as verified by the human resources department) for this leave without pay status shall be granted up to six months leave without pay under disability conditions. Leave without pay under disability conditions other than workers comp and FMLA beyond six months must be approved by the board of commissioners. (2) Employees granted leave without pay under disability conditions shall be financially responsible for the employee portion of their employee benefits during their absence. (3) No sick leave, annual leave, longevity, retirement, nor credit toward merit increases will be earned by an employee for the time the employee is on leave without pay. (4) Employees shall be responsible for informing the Human Resources department and their department head of their progress and anticipated return date. (5) An employee may return from leave without pay in the same or lower classification and pay status. (6) Employees that do not return to work when the granted leave is exhausted will be terminated and must reapply for employment with the county. (Ord. of 11-1-2010, § 22; Ord. of 8-7-2012(1); Ord. of 10-9-2012(1); Mo. of 9-10-2013; Ord. of 9-10-2013; Ord. of 6-2-2015) Sec. 2-202. - Light duty. (a) Light duty shall be defined as performing job related activities which have few or no requirements of strenuous lifting, bending, or other physical activities. (b) Light duty may be an option in a department having regular positions which only require light duty type activities. (c) An employee, released from a physician's care to return to work with light duty only, may be placed in light duty status provided that: (1) The department has regular positions with light duty type activities; and (2) The department head has the need for the employee to report for light duty work and perform such activities; and (3) The employee, if in a regular position graded higher than the grade of the light duty position, agrees to a temporary pay reduction commensurate with the light duty position. (d) An employee may work in a light duty status for a period not to exceed four weeks. (Ord. of 1-10-2012(1), § 1) Sec. 2-203. - Retirement. (a) Employees in full time positions and county commissioners are eligible for inclusion in the county's retirement plan. (b) The sheriff, tax commissioner, probate judge, clerk of court, and chief magistrate may only participate in post-retirement insurance benefits portion of the plan, provided they meet full retirement status as defined below. (c) Employees earn a vested benefit according to current plan documents which are on file in the county clerk's office. These documents detail the plan requirements and restrictions. Commissioners having served in office since 1998 or later, and having served two or more terms, are, upon reaching age 65, eligible to receive retirement benefits according to plan documents. (d) Employees and commissioners separating from county service prior to reaching full retirement status as defined below are only eligible for retirement benefits according to plan documents. Employees, sheriff, tax commissioner, probate judge, clerk of court, and chief magistrate age 60 or older and leaving county service without 20 years of service do not qualify for full retirement status. Employees, sheriff, tax commissioner, probate judge, clerk of court, and chief magistrate with 20 years of service and leaving county service prior to reaching age 60 do not qualify for full retirement status. Commissioners leaving office after age 65 but not having served two terms do not qualify for full retirement status. (e) "Full retirement status" is defined as: (1) An employee, sheriff, tax commissioner, probate judge, clerk of court, and chief magistrate with twenty or more years of full time service and retiring from county service after reaching the age of 60 or later. (2) A commissioner holding office at age 65 or older, and leaving office after reaching age 65, and having served not less than two full terms shall be defined as reaching full retirement status. (f) Post-retirement insurance benefits. Employees, commissioners, sheriff, tax commissioner, probate judge, clerk of court, and chief magistrate reaching full retirement status as defined above are eligible, upon retirement from county service, for post-retirement insurance benefits detailed below in this section: (1) Such retirees have the right to retain group health insurance at the employee rate. Retirees shall only retain health coverage held prior to retirement. After retirement, additions cannot be made to coverage. Health coverage automatically converts to supplemental (or secondary) coverage upon the employee or spouse becoming eligible for Medicare, at which time their rates are reduced to half rates. The rate reduction will be in effect only until a group supplemental plan becomes available. (2) Life insurance policies for county and voluntary coverage may have automatic reductions upon retirements and again upon reaching certain age levels. (3) Other benefits such as dental, vision, or related products usually may be retained provided the retiree continues to pay the full premiums. Disability policies terminate upon separation or retirement. (Ord. of 11-1-2010, § 23; Ord. of 2-12-2013; Ord. of 10-4-2016) Sec. 2-204. - Americans with Disability Act (1990). Polk County supports the ADA and fully complies with the standards protecting qualified applicants and employees from discrimination and providing for reasonable accommodations. (Ord. of 11-1-2010, § 24) Sec. 2-205. - Employee safety. Many job performing guidelines and operating procedures are designed to provide maximum safe working conditions for employees and the public. Employees are expected to adhere to all policies and guidelines in order to promote the safest work environment possible. (Ord. of 11-1-2010, § 25) Sec. 2-206. - Determination of full-time and part-time status for health plan eligibility. (a) Purpose. (1) The purpose of this policy is to establish procedures for establishing the "none-full-time" or "full-time status" of all new variable hour, seasonal, and ongoing county employees to determine whether or not they are eligible for health plan coverage. The county only offers health plan coverage to eligible retirees and full-time employees and their dependents. (b) Definitions. [The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section:] (1) Safe harbor methods. The methods used by the county to determine whether or not all new variable hourly, seasonal, and/or ongoing employees are eligible for health plan coverage. These methods include measurement periods, administration periods, and stability periods. (2) Full-time employee. An employee who is reasonably expected to work 30 or more hours every week and/or who works an average of 30 hours or more per week during any initial or standard measurement period. (3) None-full-time employee. An employee who works an average of 29 hours or less per week during any initial or standard measurement period. (4) Standard measurement period. A period of 12 months beginning March 31 of any current year and ending March 30 of the following year in which the weekly hours worked by ongoing employees are averaged to determine their none-full-time or full-time status. (5) Standard administrative period. A period of not more than 90 days beginning April 1 of any current year and ending June 30 of the same year in which county administration determines the eligibility of ongoing employees for health plan coverage, notifies employees regarding eligibility, and enrolls employees in the county's health plan. (6) Ongoing employee. An employee who has been employed by the county for at least one complete standard measurement period. (7) Standard stability period. A period of 12 months beginning July 1 of any current year and ending June 30 of the following year in which full-time employees and their dependents (as determined from the immediately preceding standard measurement period) are eligible to participate in the county's health plan. (8) New variable hour employee. A new employee is a variable hour employee if, based upon the facts and circumstances at his start date, it cannot be determined that the employee is reasonable expected to work on average at least 30 hours per week during the initial measurement period. (9) New seasonal employee. A new employee who is reasonably expected to work initially at least 30 hours per week for a limited period of time or on a seasonal basis and it cannot be determined that he/she is reasonably expected to work on average 30 hours per week during the initial measurement period. (10) Initial measurement period. A period of time beginning the first day of the first full calendar month immediately following a new variable hour or seasonal employee's hire date and ending ten calendar months later during which the weekly hours worked by such employees are averaged to determine their none-full-time or full-time status. (11) Initial administrative period. The total period of time between a new variable hour or seasonal employee's hire date to the beginning of the initial measurement period and including a period of one full calendar month immediately following the initial measurement period in which county administration determines whether or not a new variable hour or seasonal employee is eligible for health plan coverage, notifies the employee regarding eligibility, and enrolls the employee in the county's health plan. This period shall not extend past the last day of the first full calendar month immediately following the one-year anniversary of the employee's start date. (12) Initial stability period. A period of 12 months immediately following the initial administration period in which a new variable hour or seasonal employee, having met the requirement of a full-time employee, (as determined from the initial measurement period) is eligible to participate in the county's health plan. (c) Procedure for determining the status of new variable hour employees and seasonal employees. (1) Every new variable hour employee and seasonal employee shall be subject to an initial measurement period for the purpose of determining their none-full-time or full-time status. Immediately following the initial measurement period, the county shall be allowed an initial administrative period during which the county shall determine the status of each new employee. Also during the initial administrative period, each new employee shall be notified regarding his/her none-full-time or full-time status. Full-time employees and their dependents shall then be eligible for health plan coverage during the following initial stability period. (2) Every new variable hour and seasonal employee shall also be evaluated at the conclusion of the first full standard measurement period following his/her start date to determine his/her eligibility for county health plan coverage. The employee's status, as determined from the standard measurement period, shall dictate whether or not the employee will be eligible for health plan coverage during the following standard stability period. If an initial stability period ends prior to the start of the next standard stability period for which an employee would be eligible for health plan coverage, there shall be no lapse in health plan coverage between the two stability periods. Otherwise, the employee's health plan coverage shall end on the last day of the following full calendar month after the employee's status is determined to be none-full-time. If an initial stability period and a standard stability period overlap, and an employee is be eligible for health plan coverage during the standard stability period, health plan coverage will continue until the end of the current standard stability period. (d) Procedure for determining the status of ongoing employees. (1) Each year, during the standard administrative period, every ongoing employee shall be evaluated based upon the hours they worked during the previous standard measurement period for the purpose of determining their none-full-time or full-time status. Also during the standard administrative period, every ongoing employee shall be notified regarding his/her none-full-time or full-time status. Full-time employees and their dependents shall then be eligible for health plan coverage during the following standard stability period. (e) Average hours for none-full-time employees. (1) None-full-time employees shall be limited to an average of no more than 29 hours per week during any measurement period. (f) Administrative control. (1) The county manager shall have the authority to further restrict the hours worked by part time employees due to budgetary constraints or any other reason as determined by the manager. (g) Departmental responsibility. (1) Department heads shall be responsible for limiting the average number of weekly hours worked by a non-full-time employee (during any measurement period) to a maximum of 29 hours or any other maximum number of hours as specified by the county manager. (Ord. of 6-4-2013(3)) ARTICLE IV. - FINANCE DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Secs. 2-207—2-220. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - PURCHASES AND PROPERTY DISPOSITION
Sec. 2-221. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meaning ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Central supply means an area where materials and supplies purchased by the county for use by various departments may be secured. The purchasing agent purchases materials and supplies common to several or all departments and then dispenses such materials and supplies as needed, with the receiving department being charged the price paid by the county. Materials and supplies means and includes such items as are normally used or consumed during the course of a year and for which a general appropriation has been made; the term shall include the purchase of automotive equipment, machinery, construction contracts, or other purchases of materials of a permanent or semipermanent nature. Purchase or lease price exceeding $5,000.00 means and includes the price associated with the purchase or lease of any number of similar capital equipment units or varying unit parts, used in concert with one another, the composite budgeted total of which exceeds $5,000.00, whether purchased or leased at one time or at varying times during the fiscal year. This term shall also apply to any other phrase of similar purport which establishes the purchase or lease price requiring approval by the board of commissioners. Purchasing agent means the individual recommended by the county manager and approved by the board of commissioners to perform the duties defined in this ordinance. In the absence of a purchasing agent, such duties shall be performed by the county manager or his designee. (Ord. of 11-9-2004, § 1(2-57)) Sec. 2-222. - Purchasing department created; composition. (a) There is hereby created a purchasing department for the county. The purchasing department shall consist of a purchasing agent and such subordinate personnel as may be recommended by the county manager and approved by the board of commissioners from time to time. (b) In the absence of a purchasing agent, the county manager may designate an employee to serve in such position. (Ord. of 11-9-2004, § 1(2-58)) Sec. 2-223. - Supervision of department. The county manager shall have general supervision of the purchasing department. (Ord. of 11-9-2004, § 1(2-59)) Sec. 2-224. - Reserved. ARTICLE V. - DISPOSITION OF SURPLUS PROPERTY DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Secs. 2-225—2-241. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - PURCHASING AGENT
Sec. 2-242. - Office created; appointment; term of office. (a) There is hereby created the office of purchasing agent, who shall be appointed by the board of commissioners upon recommendation of the county manager. (b) There shall be no established term of office; provided, however, that the purchasing agent shall serve at the pleasure of the county manager. (Ord. of 11-9-2004, § 1(2-71)) Sec. 2-243. - Bond. The purchasing agent shall give a bond in the sum of $50,000.00 payable to the county, conditioned on the faithful accounting by the purchasing agent to the county for all goods and money that may come into his hands, and to indemnify and hold the county harmless for and on account of all his acts as purchasing agent. Such bonds shall be provided by the county under its blanket bond insurance policy. (Ord. of 11-9-2004, § 1(2-72)) Sec. 2-244. - Duties; generally. The purchasing agent shall have the following duties: (1) To secure prices for materials and supplies of every kind and character required by the various departments of the county regardless of the source of funds. Agencies empowered by state statute to purchase independently may have the county purchasing agent appointed as their agent for the purposes of economy and efficiency upon relinquishing such independence by the proper authority. (2) The purchasing agent shall keep complete and detailed records of all purchases and disbursement, including purchase orders issued, quotations received, basis for bid award, and any and all documents required for audit of purchase activity. (3) To inspect materials and supplies purchased by the county to determine that the materials and supplies are what they have been represented to be. (4) To determine that the prices paid for materials and supplies purchased by the county are the best that can be obtained. (5) To establish and maintain a stock of the most commonly used office supplies and other small items in a central location (central supply), so that departments may secure such items as needed. (6) To ensure that the principles of a central purchasing system are maintained. (7) Those duties prescribed in this article. (8) Such other duties as the county manager may from time to time prescribe. (Ord. of 11-9-2004, § 1(2-73)) Sec. 2-245. - Purchasing authority. (a) The purchasing agent shall have authority to make purchases or leases of capital equipment as follows: (1) The purchasing agent shall have the authority to make purchases or lease capital equipment on the open market where the purchase or lease price does not exceed $5,000.00, and where sufficient funds have been appropriated for the fiscal year in the county's budget as approved by the board of commissioners. (2) When the purchase or lease price exceeds $5,000.00 and/or insufficient funds remain in the fiscal year budget appropriations, the purchase or lease may be made by the purchasing agent only after the prospective purchase has been advertised in the official county newspaper and has been approved by the board of commissioners during a duly authorized and constituted board meeting. (3) When the equipment, materials and supplies are not included in the fiscal year budget appropriations as approved by the board of commissioners and no funds are earmarked for such purchase, the board of commissioners shall approve such purchase in advance of any solicitation for bids by the purchasing agent. (b) The purchasing agent shall have the authority to make purchases of general supplies and materials in amounts up to $5,000.00, provided such general supplies and materials are specified for purchase in the current budget, and sufficient funds are appropriated in the budget for such supplies and materials. (c) The purchasing agent shall have the authority, with approval of the county manager, to solicit bids for a set unit price for up to a 12-month period for supplies and materials which would lend themselves to such an arrangement. Materials and supplies that may be bid in such a manner include, but are not limited to: gasoline, road materials, furniture, office supplies, and others. (Ord. of 11-9-2004, § 1(2-74)) Sec. 2-246. - Inventory of county property. The finance director shall maintain a permanent inventory of all personal property of the county having a value of $500.00 or more and charged to the various county departments; provided, however, that all capital equipment, regardless of value, shall be maintained in the permanent inventory. (Ord. of 11-9-2004, § 1(2-75)) Sec. 2-247. - Inspection and testing. The purchasing agent shall inspect, or supervise the inspection of, all deliveries of materials, supplies or contractual services to determine their conformance with the specifications set forth in the pertinent purchase order or contract. The purchasing agent may require chemical and physical tests of samples submitted with bids and samples of deliveries, which examinations are necessary to determine the samples' quality and conformance with specifications. (Ord. of 11-9-2004, § 1(2-76)) Sec. 2-248. - Purchasing analysis. (a) The purchasing agent shall keep himself informed of current developments in the field of purchasing, prices, market conditions, and new products. The purchasing agent shall secure for the county the benefits of research done in the field of purchasing by other governmental jurisdictions, national technical societies, trade associations having national recognition, and by private businesses and organizations. (b) Periodically, the purchasing agent shall perform an analysis of the purchasing system to determine lead times on placing and receiving orders, average quantities used over a defined period of time, and such other information as may be appropriate or necessary to establish a "just in time" procedure. Such a procedure shall provide for better efficiency and utilization of space by having orders delivered just before stocks in central supply are depleted. (Ord. of 11-9-2004, § 1(2-77)) Sec. 2-249. - File on vendors. The purchasing agent shall maintain a file of all qualified vendors who desire to do business with the county, which file shall be maintained according to the nature of goods and materials offered, and shall contain a description of the vendors' commodities. (Ord. of 11-9-2004, § 1(2-78)) Sec. 2-250. - Cooperative purchasing. The purchasing agent shall have the authority to join with other governmental units in cooperative purchasing plans when the best interests of the county would be served thereby. (Ord. of 11-9-2004, § 1(2-79)) Secs. 2-251—2-278. - Reserved. DIVISION 3. - PURCHASING PROCEDURES
Sec. 2-279. - General purchasing requirements; exceptions. (a) All purchases for or on behalf of the county of necessary items and/or services shall be made according to the purchasing procedures specified within this division. It shall be a breach of duty on the part of any officer or employee of the county to make any purchase, or to aid or abet the making of any purchase, in any manner other than through the procedures specified within this division. (b) Any officer or employee of the county who shall make any purchase for or on behalf of the county in violation of these procedures shall be responsible for payment for the purchase, and the county shall not be responsible for any cost. Any officer or employee who shall make any purchase in violation of these procedures may additionally face disciplinary action as provided in the personnel ordinances and policies, up to and including termination. (Ord. of 11-9-2004, § 1(2-91); Ord. of 6-2-2015,) Sec. 2-280. - Credit card usage. (a) The county manager may authorize the issuance and use of credit cards to officers and/or employees of the county for the purchase of necessary items and/or services for or on behalf of the county. Officers and/or employees of the county may also be authorized to use local charge accounts established by county administration for the purchase of necessary items and/or services for or on behalf of the county. Other than constitution officers, county administration shall only be authorized to approve new vendors and establish credit accounts in the county's name. Officers and employees of the county who are authorized to use county credit accounts shall be fully responsible for any misuse of such credit accounts. (b) Any violation of this section shall subject the offending officer or employee to personal payment of unauthorized purchases, in addition to disciplinary action up to and including termination. (Ord. of 11-9-2004, § 1(2-92); Ord. of 6-2-2015) Sec. 2-281. - Purchase orders required; exception. No officer or employee of the county shall request a vendor to provide necessary items and/or services to the county except upon a regular purchase order issued by an authorized officer or employee; however, the provisions of this section shall not apply to emergency purchases provided for in this division. (Ord. of 11-9-2004, § 1(2-93); Ord. of 6-2-2015) Sec. 2-282. - Purchasing procedures. All purchases shall be made in accordance with the following procedures, except as otherwise approved by resolution or ordinance of the board of commissioners: (1) Up to $1,000.00 may be expended by a department head for routine items and services in the open market without a competitive process provided there are sufficient funds in the approved budget. (2) From $1,001.00 to $5,000.00 may be expended by the county manager or his designee, for routine items and services provided there are sufficient funds in the approved budget and provided efforts to obtain competitive quotes, including local vendor quotes, are documented. Awards shall be made according to the requirements of this section. (3) From $5,001.00 to $10,000.00, expenditures for routine items and services may be authorized by the appropriate committee provided (a) there are sufficient funds in the approved budget; (b) competitive quotes or bids have been solicited; (c) local vendors, if available, were provided with the opportunity to bid; and (d) an award is made according to the requirements of this section. Bids and/or proposals should be sealed at this level, but fax or email bids/quotes may be accepted if time is a factor. (4) The county manager or his designee shall have the authority to expend up to $5,000.00 per purchase for small tracts of land associated with public works projects. Purchases shall be reported to the full Board at the next regularly scheduled monthly business meeting. (5) The county manager or his designee shall have the authority to expend up to $10,000.00 as needed for professional services, provided there are sufficient funds in the approved budget. An effort shall be made to utilize local qualified professionals. All expenditures for professional services greater than a projected $10,000.00 require local newspaper ads, RFP's, or other similar actions in an effort to obtain three bids/proposals. All bids/proposals at this level shall be sealed. Local qualified professionals shall be provided an opportunity to submit a bid/proposal. The appropriate committee shall open and review bids/proposals at this level and consider a recommendation for the board. The board shall make a final decision. (6) All material goods and services not in the approved budget require board approval. (7) Expenditures for necessary repairs of an immediate or emergency nature may be authorized by the county manager or his designee as specified in section 2-283. As time permits, efforts will be made to obtain competitive quotes/bids. (8) Competitive bidding is not required when items/services are purchased via state contract, through ACCG or NAACO, Georgia Correctional Industries, or other federal/state programs. (9) The board of commissioners shall make awards based upon the lowest bid or proposal, meeting all of the requirements of the invitation to bid; unless other evaluation factors are specified in a request for bids or proposals. Reasons for not making an award based upon the lowest bid or proposal include, but are not limited to: a. Failure to meet all bid specifications or failure to follow bid procedures. b. History of defaulting on bids or quotes. c. History of providing unsatisfactory products or service. d. The request specified weighted evaluation factors. e. It is not in the best interest of the county. (10) In all bid situations, Polk County shall comply with O.C.G.A. § 36-91-21 and any other applicable state requirements. (11) In all bid cases, the board of commissioners retain the right to reject any or all bids or to waive formalities in the bid process. (Ord. of 11-9-2004, § 1(2-94;) Ord. of 1-8-2008(1); Ord. of 2-8-2011; Ord. of 1-10-2012(2); Ord. of 5-8-2012; Ord. of 6-2-2015) Sec. 2-283. - Emergency purchases. In emergency situations where there is an urgent need for items and/or services, during normal county business hours by any department of the county, the department head shall act within his/her purchasing authority to acquire the needed items and services. If the purchase of urgently needed items and/or services exceeds the department heads purchasing authority, the department head shall contact the county manager or his designee for authorization to proceed. In emergency situations where there is an urgent need for items and/or services, outside of normal county business hours by any department of the county, the department head shall make a determination as to whether or not an emergency situation exists. If the department head determines that an actual emergency exists, he/she shall attempt to contact the county manager or his designee for authorization to proceed. If the county manager or his designee cannot be contacted, the department head shall be authorized to make the necessary purchase to address the situation. The department head shall document the emergency purchase and report it immediately to the county manager or his designee during normal county business hours. If an emergency should arise at any time, during or outside of normal county business hours, which would require the immediate maintenance or repair of county facilities or equipment, the department head involved shall immediately notify the county maintenance director and/or county management so that immediate action can be taken to protect county property. In all cases, emergency purchases made to secure items and/or services that exceed the purchasing authority of section 2-282 of this division, shall be duly documented and reported to the board of commissioners. (Ord. of 11-9-2004, § 1(2-95); Ord. of 6-2-2015) Sec. 2-284. - Preparation of requests for bids and proposals. Department heads shall coordinate with the purchasing agent and/or county administration to prepare written bid/proposal requests and specifications for the procurement of items and/or services requiring bids/proposals as outlined in section 2-282. Written requests for bids/proposals shall be as detailed as possible. Bid/proposal requests shall permit and encourage free and open competition. (Ord. of 11-9-2004, § 1(2-96); Ord. of 6-2-2015) Sec. 2-285. - Filing of bids; public inspection. All bids/proposals submitted for items and/or services to be acquired by the county under the provisions of this division shall be kept on file in the county clerk's office. After an award has been made, bids/proposals shall be subject to inspection at any time by any citizen of the county. (Ord. of 11-9-2004, § 1(2-99); Ord. of 6-2-2015) Sec. 2-286. - Disqualification of bidder. The county manager or his designee shall have the authority to declare a vendor who defaults on a bid/proposal to be an irresponsible bidder and to disqualify him from receiving any business from the county for a specified period of time. (Ord. of 11-9-2004, § 1(2-100); Ord. of 6-2-2015) Sec. 2-287. - Purchasing cards and credit cards for elected officials. (a) Intent and scope. This section is intended to comply with the policy requirements of O.C.G.A. § 36-80-24 regarding the use of county issued government purchasing cards and credit cards. (b) Definitions. (1) "Authorized elected official" means an elected official or their designated employee authorized by public vote of the board of commissioners to possess and use a county issued government purchasing card or credit card. (2) "Card administrator" means the purchasing card and credit card administrator designated by the Polk County Board of Commissioners. (3) "County" means Polk County and/or the board of commissioners. (4) "County purchase card," "county p-card" or "county credit card" means a financial transaction card issued by any business organization, financial institution, or any duly authorized agent of such organization or institution, used by a county official to purchase goods, services and other things of value on behalf of the county. (5) "Financial transaction card" means an instrument or device as the term is defined in O.C.G.A. § 16-9-30(5). (6) "User agreement" means the required agreement between the board of commissioners and the authorized elected officials which restricts the use of a county purchasing card or credit card. (c) Authorized elected officials. The Polk County Board of Commissioners ("county"), in its discretion, may authorize specific county elected officials or their designated users to use a county purchasing card or credit card by adoption of a resolution in a public meeting. No authorized elected official or their designated user may use a county purchasing card or credit card until and unless he or she has executed the county's purchasing card and credit card user agreement. The county will not make payments to any business organization, financial institution, or any duly authorized agent of such organization or institution, for amounts charged by an elected official to any purchasing cards or credit cards that are not issued pursuant to this section or for any purchases that are not authorized by this section. (d) Card administrator. The board of commissioners shall designate the county Purchasing Agent as the county purchasing card and credit card administrator. The responsibilities of the Card Administrator include: (1) Manage county issued purchasing cards and credit cards. (2) Serve as the main point of contact for all county purchasing card and credit card issues. (3) Serve as liaison to the elected officials authorized to use a purchasing card or credit card and their staff, as well as to the issuer of the purchasing card or credit card. (4) Provide training on card policies and procedures to the elected officials authorized to use a purchasing card or credit card and their staff. (5) Develop internal procedures to ensure timely payment of cards. (6) Assist authorized elected officials to dispute transactions when necessary. (7) Establish internal procedures to ensure compliance with this section, county procurement ordinances and policies, county purchasing card and credit card user agreements, applicable agreements with the business organization, financial institution, or any duly authorized agent of such organization or institution, issuing card, and state law, specifically, O.C.G.A. §§ 16-9-37 and 36-80-24. (8) Document internal controls, audits and other measures to prevent and detect misuse or abuse of the cards. (9) Audit and reconcile transactions monthly. (10) Maintain records for at least seven years or as otherwise provided by the county's record retention policy. (e) Use of cards. (1) Authorized purchases. County purchase cards and credit cards may be used to purchase goods and services directly related to the public duties of the authorized elected official only. All purchases are subject to the terms of this section, the county purchasing card and credit card user agreement, county procurement policies and ordinances, and the adopted budget. Only authorized elected officials and/or their designated employee(s) may use a county purchasing card and/or credit card for purchases or payments. The cards, and use of the cards, are not transferrable. The authorized elected official and/or designated employee(s) shall use care to ensure that others do not have access to the card account number, expiration date and security code. Unless otherwise approved by the governing authority or established in the county purchasing card and credit card user agreement, the transaction limits are as follows: Per month: $ Limit set on each card. (2) Unauthorized purchases. County purchasing cards and credit cards shall not be used for goods and services not directly related to the official responsibilities of the authorized elected official. Additionally, cards shall not be used to avoid compliance with the county's purchasing ordinances and procedures, to purchase goods and services that are not approved in the county's budget, to purchase goods and services exceeding the per transaction or per month limit, or to make purchases not in compliance with the county purchasing card and credit card user agreement. (3) Receipts and documentation. Receipts, invoices and other supporting documentation of all purchases made with a county purchasing card or credit card shall be obtained and maintained by the authorized county elected official for five years or as otherwise provided by the county's record retention policy. If an original or duplicate cannot be produced, a sworn affidavit of the authorized elected official may be substituted. The documentation must include the supplier or merchant information (i.e., name and location), quantity, description, unit price, total price, price paid without sales tax and an explanation of the purchase sufficient to show that the expense was in the performance of official county duties. (4) Public Records. All receipt and other documentation of purchases are public records and subject to the requirements of O.C.G.A. § 50-18-70 et seq. (f) Review of purchases and audit. Proper documentation of purchases, internal controls and other measures prevent and allow detection to misuse or abuse of county issued purchase cards and credit cards. Authorized elected officials and staff that process payments under this program shall cooperate and comply with the procedures established by the county. (1) Review of purchases. All purchases shall be reviewed according to the following procedure: The Polk County Finance Department shall review all purchasing and/or credit card statements prior to final approval from county administration. (2) Audits. The card administrator shall perform an annual review of the card program to ensure adequacy of internal policies and procedures, cardholder spending limits, monthly reconciliation procedures and documentation for transactions. elected officials and staff shall cooperate with such review. (g) Violations. (1) An elected official shall reimburse the county for any purchases made with a county issued purchase card or credit card in violation of this section or the user agreement. (2) In the discretion of the county governing authority, failure to comply with the procedures outlined in this section may result in: i. A warning; ii. Suspension of the elected official's authority to use a county purchase card or credit card; or iii. Revocation of the elected official's authority to use a county i purchase card or credit card. (3) Nothing in this section shall preclude the county governing authority from referring misuse of a purchase card or credit card for prosecution to the appropriate authorities. (Ord. of 12-8-2015(1)) Secs. 2-288—2-310. - Reserved. Editor's note— An ordinance of June 2, 2015 repealed §§ 2-285, 2-286, 2-289 and 2-290 which pertained to purchasing procedures and derived from Ord. of 11-9-2014, § 1(2-97—2-103). Former §§ 2-287 and 2-288 have been renumbered as §§ 2-285 and 2-286 as set out herein. DIVISION 4. - SALE OF COUNTY PROPERTY
Sec. 2-311. - Sales of personal property. (a) When it is deemed advisable to dispose of any personal property owned by the county and used by the various departments thereof, or to dispose of personal property under the supervision of the board of commissioners, the sale of the property shall be made by the purchasing agent. The board of commissioners shall order the disposition of personal property by either: sealed bids, auction, or other methods. The purchasing agent shall confer with the head of the department desiring to sell the property, with the object of getting the best possible price in making the sale. (b) This section shall not authorize the sale of county personal property without authorization therefor by a resolution of the board of commissioners, but where a resolution has authorized the sale of county personal property, the sale shall be made by the purchasing agent in conformity with subsection (a) of this section. (Ord. of 11-9-2004, § 1(2-111)) Sec. 2-312. - Disposal of unserviceable property. (a) When any personal property owned by the county has become worn out, useless, or junk, or has been used to such an extent that it is advisable to dispose of it, the head of the department in charge of the property shall certify to the county manager that certain itemized property in the custody of the department is no longer useful in the service of the county. Upon such certification, the county manager shall direct the purchasing agent to sell such unserviceable property at public sale by one of the methods allowed herein, and remit the proceeds from the sale to the finance director, who shall deposit the proceeds into the county's general fund. (b) No sales of unserviceable county personal property shall be made by the purchasing agent under this section, where other provisions of law provide for such sales, but this section shall apply to the sale of unserviceable county personal property where no other provision of law is made. However, the purchasing agent shall have the authority to dispose of junk accumulated by the various departments of the county to the best advantage of the county, by selling, trading the junk or transferring it to another department, whichever, in the discretion of the purchasing agent, will be most advantageous to the county. (Ord. of 11-9-2004, § 1(2-112)) Sec. 2-313. - Notice of transfer or disposal of property. All transfers of personal property from one department of the county to another, and all property disposed of shall be reported to the finance director immediately. (Ord. of 11-9-2004, § 1(2-113)) Secs. 2-314—2-330. - Reserved. ARTICLE VI. - BOARDS, COMMISSIONS AND AUTHORITIES DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
Secs. 2-331—2-345. - Reserved. DIVISION 2. - COUNTY DEVELOPMENT AUTHORITY[4]
Footnotes: --- (4) --- State Law reference— Development Authorities Law, O.C.G.A. § 36-62-1 et seq.
Sec. 2-346. - Finding of need. There is hereby determined and declared a pressing, existing and future need for a development authority (as more fully described and defined in the Development Authorities Law (O.C.G.A. § 36-62-1 et seq.)) to function in the county for the purpose of developing and promoting for the public good and general welfare trade, commerce, industry and employment opportunities in said county thereby promoting the general welfare of its citizenry. (Code 1974, § 6-16; Res. of 9-10-1970) Sec. 2-347. - Created. There is hereby activated in the county, the public body corporate and politic known as the Development Authority of Polk County which was created upon the adoption and approval of the Development Authorities Law (O.C.G.A. § 36-62-1 et seq.) and particularly O.C.G.A. § 36-62-4. (Code 1974, § 6-17; Res. of 9-10-1970) Sec. 2-348. - Composition. The development authority shall be composed of seven members, designated as directors, each of whom shall be a taxpayer of the county and none of whom shall be an officer or employee of this county. (Code 1974, § 6-18; Res. of 9-10-1970) State Law reference— Development authority composition, O.C.G.A. § 36-63-4. Sec. 2-349. - Appointment. (a) The directors of the county development authority shall be appointed by the board of commissioners as follows: five citizens of the county are appointed as directors by the board of commissioners; one citizen nominated each by the City of Cedartown and the City of Rockmart and such nominations are to be confirmed as directors by the board of commissioners. (b) In addition, the following shall serve as ex-officio (non-voting) members of the authority: (1) A county commissioner appointed by the BOC chairman. (2) A representative appointed by the City of Cedartown. (3) A representative appointed by the City of Rockmart. (4) A representative appointed by the county water authority. (5) A representative appointed by the Georgia Power Company. (6) Other ex-officio members as deemed appropriate by the development authority board of directors. (Code 1974, § 6-19; Res. of 9-10-1970; Ord. of 6-5-2012(2)) State Law reference— Appointment of members of development authority composition, O.C.G.A. § 36-63-4. Sec. 2-350. - Terms. Those persons appointed as directors of the development authority shall serve for terms of four years and until their successors have been appointed and qualified. (Code 1974, § 6-20; Res. of 9-10-1970) State Law reference— Terms of members of development authority, O.C.G.A. § 36-63-4. Sec. 2-351. - Organization. The board of directors of the development authority shall organize itself, carry out its duties and responsibilities and exercise its powers and prerogatives in accordance with the terms and provisions of the Development Authorities Law (O.C.G.A. § 36-62-1 et seq.). (Code 1974, § 6-21; Res. of 9-10-1970) Sec. 2-352. - Exclusion. Action taken by the board of commissioners as hereinbefore specified is not intended in any way to affect the Cedartown development authority, including, without limitation, its existence, purpose, organization, powers or function. (Code 1974, § 6-22; Res. of 9-10-1970) Secs. 2-353—2-377. - Reserved. DIVISION 3. - JOINT DEVELOPMENT AUTHORITY
Sec. 2-378. - Activation of the authority. It is hereby declared that there is a need for a joint development authority to function in Polk County, Haralson County, Heard County and Carroll County. Such authority, to be known as the Joint Development Authority of Polk County, Haralson County, Heard County and Carroll County, is hereby created and activated. Said authority, herein called the authority, shall transact business pursuant to, and exercise the powers provided by the provisions of, the Development Authorities Law, codified in the O.C.G.A. title 36, ch. 62 (O.C.G.A. § 36-62-1 et seq.). (Res. of 12-6-1994, § 1) Sec. 2-379. - Joint authority. The authority is created and activated by this proper resolution of the governing bodies of Polk County, Haralson County, Heard County and Carroll County as a joint authority pursuant to the provisions of O.C.G.A. § 36-62-5.1. (Res. of 12-6-1994, § 1) Sec. 2-380. - Directors. (a) The number of members of the authority shall be nine. Two members shall be taxpayers residing in the county and shall be appointed initially, as provided in this resolution and, thereafter, by the board of commissioners of the county as their terms expire. Two members shall be taxpayers residing in Haralson County and shall be appointed initially, as provided in this resolution and, thereafter, by the commissioner of Haralson County as their terms expire. Two members shall be taxpayers residing in Heard County and shall be appointed initially, as provided in this resolution and, thereafter, by the board of commissioners of Heard County as their terms expire. Two members shall be taxpayers residing in Carroll County and shall be appointed initially, as provided in this resolution and, thereafter, by the board of commissioners of Carroll County as their terms expire. The ninth member of the authority shall be appointed for an initial term of two years by the first governing body to approve this joint resolution, and shall be appointed thereafter at the expiration of each two-year term by the governing body next succeeding the governing body previously appointing such director, such succession determined as follows: commissioner of Haralson County shall succeed the board of commissioners of Carroll County, the board of commissioners of Heard County shall succeed the commissioner of Haralson County, the board of commissioners of Polk County shall succeed the board of commissioners of Heard County, and the board of commissioners of Carroll County shall succeed the board of commissioners of Polk County. No director shall be an officer or employee of Carroll County, Haralson County, Heard County or Polk County. The members shall receive no compensation for their services, but shall be reimbursed for their actual expenses incurred in the performance of their duties. (b) After expiration of the initial terms, the terms of office of all members shall be terms of two years. Successors to the persons listed above shall be appointed by the governing body of Carroll County, Haralson County, Heard County and Polk County, as applicable, shown opposite such person's name as shown above. If at the end of any term of any member, a successor to such member has not been appointed, the member whose term of office has expired shall continue to hold office until his successor is appointed. A majority of the members of the authority shall constitute a quorum, but no action may be taken by the authority without the affirmative vote of a majority of the full membership of the authority. (Res. of 12-6-1994, § 3) Sec. 2-381. - Officers. The directors shall elect one of their members as chairman and another as vice-chairman and shall also elect a secretary and a treasurer or a secretary-treasurer, either of who may, but need not be, a director. (Res. of 12-6-1994, § 4) Secs. 2-382—2-405. - Reserved. DIVISION 4. - CEDARTOWN-POLK COUNTY HOSPITAL AUTHORITY
Sec. 2-406. - Finding of need. There is a need for a hospital authority to function in the county, as contemplated under the Hospital Authorities Law (O.C.G.A. § 31-7-70 et seq.) . (Code 1974, § 7-16; Res. of 5-3-1946) Sec. 2-407. - Created. There is hereby created and constituted a public body corporate and politic to be known as the "Cedartown-Polk County Hospital Authority" with all rights, powers, privileges and immunities provided for in the Hospital Authorities Law (O.C.G.A. § 31-7-70 et seq.). (Code 1974, § 7-17; Res. of 5-3-1946; Res. of 10-25-1949) Sec. 2-408. - Composition. The board of trustees provided for in O.C.G.A. § 31-7-72 shall consist of seven citizens of the county. (Code 1974, § 7-18; Res. of 5-3-1946) Sec. 2-409. - Election of trustees. All trustees shall be elected by the other trustees. (Code 1974, § 7-20; Res. of 5-3-1946) Sec. 2-410. - Terms. Each trustee shall be elected to serve for a term of seven years and until his successor is elected and qualified. (Code 1974, § 7-21; Res. of 5-3-1946) Sec. 2-411. - Vacancies. All vacancies in the membership of said board of trustees, whether by expiration of term or otherwise, shall be filled by the remaining trustees, and any trustee elected to fill an unexpired term shall serve for the remaining portion of such term, and until his successor is elected and qualified. (Code 1974, § 7-22; Res. of 5-3-1946) Secs. 2-412—2-435. - Reserved. DIVISION 5. - REGIONAL HOUSING AUTHORITY[5]
Footnotes: --- (5) --- State Law reference— Regional housing authorities, O.C.G.A. § 8-3-100 et seq.
Sec. 2-436. - Finding of need. There is a need for one regional housing authority to be created for Bartow, Catoosa, Chattooga, Dade, Floyd, Gordon, Haralson, Paulding, Polk and Walker counties to exercise in such counties powers and other functions prescribed for a regional housing authority. (Code 1974, § 8-16; Res. of 11-3-1970, § 1) Sec. 2-437. - Name. The name of the regional housing authority shall be the Coosa Valley Regional Housing Authority. (Code 1974, § 8-17; Res. of 11-3-1970, § 3) Sec. 2-438. - Member appointed. The board of commissioners shall appoint one member to the regional housing authority. (Code 1974, § 8-18; Res. of 11-3-1970, § 2) State Law reference— Composition of regional housing authority, O.C.G.A. § 8-3-106. Secs. 2-439—2-499. - Reserved. ARTICLE VII. - TRAINING AND TRAVEL
Sec. 2-500. - Purpose. This policy is designed to provide county employees with guidelines for requesting and documenting the use of county funds for training and/or travel purposes. (Ord. of 10-14-08) Sec. 2-501. - Definitions. [The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:] Advance payment. Approved payment made by the county to an employee for planned expenses prior to a training and/or travel event. Payments must be documented with original receipts for all expenditures excluding meals. Commercial transportation. Any entity providing transportation of people or goods for pay. Direct payment. Approved payment made by the county directly to vendors for training and/or travel expenses incurred by county employees. Payments must be documented with original receipts for all expenditures excluding meals. Expenses. Approved expenditures incurred by county employees for training and/or travel relating to an employees job duties or responsibilities. Allowable expenses are limited to registration, tuition, actual lodging cost for standard rooms, meals and tips, mileage, parking fees, commercial transportation, and other expenses as approved by the county manager and/or the board of commissioners. Lodging. A hotel, motel, inn, apartment, or similar entity that furnishes lodging to the public for pay. Reimbursement. Approved payment made by the county to an employee for allowable expenses following the completion of training and/or travel that was paid for with personal funds. Payments must be documented with original receipts for all expenditures excluding meals. Training. A conference, meeting, workshop, seminar, session, convention, or school directly related to an employees job duties or responsibilities. Travel. A single or multiple-day trip completed as a necessary part of job duties and/or is necessary to attend approved training. (Ord. of 10-14-08) Sec. 2-502. - Training and travel approval. The following qualifications shall be met prior to approval of all employee training and/or travel requests: (1) Funds for training must be allocated in current budget. (2) Travel is directly related to an employees job duties or responsibilities. (3) Travel is a necessary part of job duties and/or is necessary to attend approved training. (4) Must have approval from department head. (5) Must have approval from county manager. (6) Training and/or travel is within the State of Georgia. (Ord. of 10-14-08) Sec. 2-503. - Special approval. Special approval for training and/or travel shall be required from the board of commissioners in the following cases: (1) Training and travel requiring an amendment to the current budget. (2) Training and travel outside the State of Georgia. (3) Other training and travel not authorized by this policy. (Ord. of 10-14-08) Sec. 2-504. - Allowable expenses. The following are training and travel expenses that are typically eligible for payment under this policy based upon prior approval: (1) Registration, tuition, or related fees. (2) Actual lodging cost for standard room. (3) Meal costs and tips not to exceed the following per day: Breakfast * \$ 5.00 Lunch\12.50 Dinner ** \17.50 Tips\15% * Breakfast shall not be paid for single day trips and will only be paid for the second and subsequent days of travel. ** Dinner shall only be paid in the event that travel extends past 8:00 p.m. (4) Mileage for the use of an employee's personal vehicle associated with approved training and/or travel at the rate of $0.34 per actual mile. (5) Parking and toll fees. (6) Commercial transportation (airplane, train, bus, taxi etc.). (7) Fuel for county vehicles. (8) Other related or necessary travel expenses with prior approval from the county manager or the board of commissioners. (Ord. of 10-14-08) Sec. 2-505. - Non-allowable expenses. The following expenses shall not be allowed for payment by the county: (1) Personal leisure or entertainment activities. (2) Alcoholic beverages. (3) Between meal snacks or drinks. (4) Maintenance or repairs of personal vehicles. (5) Fuel cost for personal vehicles. (6) Gifts or personal purchases. (7) Expenditures for non-authorized persons and/or employees. (8) Any other expenses determined by the county manager or the board of commissioners to be non-allowable. (Ord. of 10-14-08) Sec. 2-506. - Requests for training and/or travel. (a) Requests for training and/or travel shall typically be made at least two weeks prior to the date of training and/or travel within the State of Georgia and at least four weeks prior to the date of training and/or travel outside of the State of Georgia. Training and/or travel request made less than two weeks prior to the date of training and/or travel will be considered on a case-by-case basis. (b) Completed travel request forms, available from the finance department, shall be submitted to department heads for departmental review and approval. Following departmental approval, travel request shall be forwarded to the county manager for approval. Travel request forms shall include a detailed training/travel itinerary (i.e. travel schedules and training brochures) and a detailed itemization of expenses associated with the travel request. (c) Approved expenses associated with training and/or travel shall be paid by one or more of the following methods with approval by the county manager. (1) Reimbursement payment. (2) Advance payment. If actual authorized expenses are greater than the amount of an advance payment, then the difference shall be reimbursed to the employee. If such expenses are less than the amount of an advance payment, then the difference shall be immediately paid to the commissioners office. (3) Direct payment. If a direct payment is made, and is nonrefundable, the employee may be held liable for reimbursement to the county if the employee fails to attend without valid cause. The board of commissioners or personnel committee shall make a determination in such cases. (d) Within five days following training and/or travel, a settlement of expenses must be completed and submitted to the finance department. Original receipts for all qualifying expenses, excluding meals, shall be submitted as part of this settlement. (Ord. of 10-14-08) Sec. 2-507. - Travel pay. (a) Hourly rate employees. (1) Required training. When training is required by the county, an employee shall be paid for actual travel time and actual time spent in training. Sleep and leisure time shall not qualify for pay. (2) Optional training. When training is optional (not required by the county, but is approved as job related), an employee shall be paid for the lessor of actual travel and training time or eight hours per day.
