(3) Required travel. When travel is required as part of normal job duties, an employee shall be paid for actual time. (4) Overtime. a. When training and/or travel are required as outlined above, then such actual hours shall apply toward the accrual of overtime. b. A department head shall obtain the approval of the county manager prior to requiring employees to attend training. (5) Miscellaneous training. An employee requesting training and/or travel which is neither required or job related may, at the discretion of the department head, be granted leave without pay to attend without the county's participation in associated expenses. (b) Salaried employees. (1) Required/optional training. When a salaried employee attends required or optional training, the employee shall be paid his or her regular salary. If training is required during an employee's normal off day, the employee may be eligible for comp time off with the approval of both the department head and the county manager. (2) Miscellaneous training. A salaried employee requesting to attend training and/or travel that is neither required or job related may, at the discretion of the department head, be granted leave without pay to attend without the county's participation in associated expenses. (Ord. of 10-14-08) Sec. 2-508. - Training and travel policy amendment. This policy may be amended as necessary by a three-fifths majority vote of the board of commissioners. (Ord. of 10-14-08) Sec. 2-509—2-530. - Reserved.

div.head: Chapter 6 - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES
div.p:
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL
Secs. 6-1—6-18. - Reserved. ARTICLE II. - MALT BEVERAGES
Sec. 6-19. - Definitions. Unless the context or the specific provisions of this article demand otherwise, the words and terms used in this article shall have the same definition and meaning as set forth in this section and in O.C.G.A. title 3 (O.C.G.A. § 3-1-1 et seq.). Alcohol or alcoholic beverage means malt beverage. Applicant means the actual owner of a business establishment for which an alcoholic beverage license is requested. Authorized catered function means a scheduled special social event, contest, reception, party, or similar activity for which a food caterer or event venue has prepared substantial food items to be served with appropriate serving facilities and personnel. Building inspector means the Building Inspector for Polk County. Business location means the location of a retail or wholesale outlet. Drink means any bottle, can, or glass of malt beverage served for consumption on the premises, which may or may not be diluted by any other non-alcoholic liquid. Event venue means a site, place, or location satisfying all of the requirements of this article, upon which authorized catered functions are hosted. In addition, an event venue shall be equipped with a sanitary kitchen suitable for catered food or if food is prepared on premises, a sanitary kitchen approved for food service by the county health department. Section 6-41 shall not apply to event venues. Event venues shall also comply with section 6-28(c) prohibited locations, of this Code. Food caterer means an individual or business possessing a valid food service permit issued by a Georgia County Health Department and any other license or certificate as may be required, that prepares food for consumption off the premises. Immediate family means spouse, mother, father, brother or sister. Licensed alcoholic beverage caterer means any person, firm, or corporation who has been licensed pursuant to the provisions of this article and O.C.G.A. § 3-11-2 to sell alcoholic beverages by the bottle, glass, or other open container for consumption on the premises of an event venue or special event venue. Licensee means the person to whom an alcoholic beverage license has been issued, or in the case of a partnership, corporation or other legal entity, all partners, officers, and directors of such entity. Malt beverage means any alcoholic beverage obtained by the fermentation of any infusion or decoction of barley, malt, hops, or any other similar product, or any combination of such products in water, containing not more than 14 percent alcohol by volume and including ale, porter, brown, stout, lager beer, small beer, and strong beer. The term does not include sake, known as Japanese rice wine. O.C.G.A. § 3-1-2. Outlet means a store or business where malt beverages are sold. Outlet manager means that person who does or will actually manage or operate the outlet on a day-to-day basis. Package means a bottle, can, keg, barrel, or other original consumer container. Purchase price means the consideration received for the sale of alcoholic beverages by the drink, valued in money, whether received in cash or otherwise, including all receipts, cash credits, and property of services of any kind or nature, and also the amount for which credit is allowed by the licensee to the purchaser, without any deduction therefrom whatsoever. Purchaser means any person who orders and gives present or future consideration for any alcoholic beverage by the package or drink. Qualified business owner means the actual owner of a business establishment who holds an occupational certificate issued by the county. Restaurant means any public place kept, used, maintained, advertised, and held out to the public as a place where meals are served and where meals are actually regularly prepared and served, and without sleeping accommodations, and holds a valid food service permit from the county health department, and has seating capacity for at least 24 people, and has adequate and sanitary kitchen and dining facilities, and serves at least one full course meal for not less than three days a week for not less than three months a calendar year, and serving of meals is the principal business conducted, and the serving of malt beverages to be consumed on premises as only incidental thereto, and malt beverages shall only be served during such times full course meals are actually being served. Special event means an event conducted by or for the benefit of a certified nonprofit or civic organization at an approved venue. At least 50 percent of the proceeds from the event must be given to a nonprofit or civic organization. Special event organizer(s) means any person, firm, or corporation who is responsible for promoting and/or conducting a special event. Special event venue means a site, place, or location satisfying all of the requirements of this article upon which a special event may be hosted. Section 6-41 shall not apply to special event venues. Special event venues shall also comply with section 6-28(c), prohibited locations, of this Code. (Res. of 1-16-1966, § 1; Res. of 6-14-2004, § 1; Ord. of 4-5-11; Res. of 8-6-2013; Ord. No. 2016-03, § 1) Sec. 6-20. - Necessity for license; unlawful activity. It shall be unlawful to manufacture, sell, offer to sell, or possess for the purpose of sale, at wholesale or retail, within the unincorporated areas of the county, any malt beverages, without having the appropriate license for such manufacture or sale, or to carry on such activity in violation of the terms of such license or of the resolution from which this article is derived. (Res. of 1-16-1966, § 2) State Law reference— County licensing of malt beverages, O.C.G.A. § 3-5-40 et seq. Sec. 6-21. - Classification of licenses. The following types or classes of licenses will be available within this county: (1) Retail package outlet. The retail package outlet license shall permit only the sale at retail of malt beverages in packages. On-premises consumption shall be prohibited. (2) Pouring outlet. The pouring outlet license shall permit the sale of malt beverages only by the bottle, glass, or other open container for consumption inside a restaurant as defined in section 6-19, Definitions, and section 6-41, Supplemental requirements. (3) Wholesale distributor. The wholesale distributor license shall permit only the sale of malt beverages at wholesale. (4) Alcoholic beverage caterer. The alcoholic beverage caterer license shall permit the sale or distribution of malt beverages by the bottle, glass or other open container for consumption on the premises of an event venue hosting authorized catered functions. This license is not transferable. (5) Special event permit. The special event permit shall permit the sale or distribution of malt beverages by the bottle, glass, or other open container for consumption, out of the view of any public right-of-way or adjacent properties, on the premises of an approved special event venue. This permit is not transferable. (Res. of 1-16-1966, § 3; Ord. of 3-8-11; Res. of 8-6-2013) Sec. 6-22. - Separate license for each malt beverage outlet; terms of transfer. (a) A separate license shall be required for each malt beverage outlet and a separate application shall be made for each such outlet and business location. (b) Transfer of licenses between business locations is prohibited. (c) The transfer of malt beverage license from one individual or entity to another shall be prohibited. (d) Malt beverage licenses shall only be issued to qualified business owners. (Res. of 1-16-1966, § 4; Res. of 8-6-2013) Sec. 6-23. - Initial application for license. (a) Form and contents . Each initial application for a malt beverage license shall be made under oath, in writing, on forms supplied by the county manager or designee, and shall contain the following information: (1) The type of license for which application is made. (2) The full name, age, home address, business address, name of spouse and minor children, and complete disclosure of all convictions and pleas of guilty and nolo contendere for violations of city, state and federal laws of each applicant and spouse. (3) The full name, age, home address, business address, name of spouse and all minor children, and complete disclosure of all convictions and pleas of guilty and nolo contendere for violations of city, state and federal laws of the proposed outlet manager. (4) Exact location of the proposed outlet. (5) Name and address of owner, landlord and resident manager of location for proposed outlet. (6) Whether or not the building for the proposed outlet has been erected as the proposed location. (7) Trade name or proposed trade name of business. (8) Names and addresses of all persons having any financial interest whatsoever in the proposed outlet including but not limited to ownership of building or property, ownership of stock in business or receipt of income from business. (9) Whether or not the applicant has ever held a license for the sale of malt beverages and, if so, the dates held, the authority issuing such license, the current status of such license, whether or not such license was revoked, and the reasons for any such revocation. (10) Such other information as may be required by the board of commissioners. (11) A copy of the applicant's application or proposed application for license issued by the state shall be attached to the application form. (b) Fee . Each initial application shall be accompanied by a nonrefundable application fee in the amount established by the resolution for investigation of the applicant and proposed business location and for processing of the application. (c) Fingerprints . Each initial application shall be accompanied by a complete set of fingerprints of the applicant and/or the proposed outlet manager to be forwarded to the Georgia Bureau of Investigation for search and investigation as provided in O.C.G.A. § 3-3-2. (d) Proof of advertisement . Proof of compliance with the advertisement requirements as set forth in section 6-25 shall be filed by the applicant prior to consideration of the application. (Res. of 1-16-1966, § 5; Res. of 6-14-2004(1), § 5; Res. of 6-14-2004(2), § 2) Sec. 6-24. - Waiting list. Any application for a retail package store or pouring outlet license filed at a time when no such licenses are available shall be placed on a waiting list and shall be considered in its proper order at such time as a vacancy occurs. For an application to be placed on the waiting list, the applicant must comply with all requirements for initial application except proof of advertisement. Upon notification by the county manager or designee that a vacancy exists, the applicant shall comply with the advertisement requirements set forth in section 6-25 and file proof of such compliance within 30 days following such notification. If no proof of advertisement is filed within the 30-day period, the application shall be removed from the waiting list and the applicant shall be ineligible to reapply for a period of one year following such removal. (Res. of 1-16-1966, § 6) Sec. 6-25. - Proof of advertisement. (a) Publication of notice . Upon filing an application for a malt beverage license, the applicant shall publish a notice of his application in The Cedartown Standard and The Rockmart Journal once a week for two weeks. Such notice shall contain the name of the applicant, the type of license for which application is made, the proposed business location, and the name of the proposed outlet manager. (b) Posting of notice . Within three days after filing an application for a malt beverage license, the applicant shall post a sign on the proposed business location. The sign shall be not less than 24 inches in height and 36 inches in width, with letters of at least 2½ inches in height and shall be captioned, "malt beverage license application pending." It shall designate the name and address of the applicant, the type of license, and the date of application and shall contain no other advertisement. The sign shall be posted on the front door of the building to be used if said door faces the right-of-way of the street upon which the building fronts, otherwise, the sign shall be posted facing the street and within three feet of said right-of-way. If a building is to be constructed on the location, the sign shall be posted facing the street and within three feet of the right-of-way of the street upon which the building will front. (c) Cost . Cost of advertisement as provided herein shall be borne by the applicant. (d) Proof of advertisement . The applicant shall file the following with the county manager or designee within 30 days following the filing of the initial application: (1) A copy of the newspaper advertisements, together with the publisher's affidavits stating the dates of publication. (2) A photograph of the sign posted on the proposed business location together with an affidavit stating that the sign was erected as required herein. (Res. of 1-16-1966, § 7) Sec. 6-26. - Procedure for grant or denial of license; subsequent applicant. (a) Within seven days after the filing of the proof of advertisement, the county manager or designee shall refer the application to the chief of the county police department for investigation. The board of commissioners shall consider the application, the investigation, the report of the chief of the county police department and any objections filed. (b) Upon written request of the applicant, the board of commissioners shall conduct a public hearing prior to making a decision. No decision shall be made except at a regular meeting of the board of commissioners. Should the application be granted, a written notice shall be given to the applicant and a license shall be issued upon payment of the appropriate licensing fee. Should the application be denied, written notice setting forth the reasons for denial shall be given to the applicant. (c) In the event an application is denied, the applicant shall be ineligible to reapply for a period of one year from the date of denial. (Res. of 1-16-1966, § 8) Sec. 6-27. - Guidelines for the consideration of applications for malt beverage licenses. The following factors shall be considered in determining whether or not to grant a malt beverage license: (1) The proximity of other licensed malt beverage sales outlets to the proposed business location; (2) The nature of the neighborhood immediately adjacent to the proposed business location; that is, whether the same is predominantly residential, commercial or industrial; (3) The proximity of churches, hospitals, schools, college campuses, public parks, playgrounds and private residences; (4) The availability of adequate off street parking facilities for patrons; (5) The possibility of increased traffic congestion and traffic hazards; (6) The criminal record, financial responsibility, character and reputation of the applicant, owners or stockholders of the applicant, and proposed outlet manager; (7) The compliance with all application and advertisement requirements; (8) The need for additional business facilities selling malt beverages within the county; (9) The revocation for cause of any previous license for the sale of malt beverages issued to the applicant or proposed outlet manager; or for the proposed business location; (10) The history or reputation of the proposed business location for prostitution or other sex offenses, fighting, shooting, stabbing or violence, gambling, illegal drug dealing in alcoholic beverages or drugs, or other violations of the law. (Res. of 1-16-1966, § 9) Sec. 6-28. - Grounds for denial of license. (a) Denial of license. An application for a malt beverage license may be denied if it is determined based upon the factors set forth in section 6-27 that the granting of such license would be detrimental to the public safety, health or welfare of the residents of the county. (b) Prohibited persons. An application for a malt beverage license shall be denied to the following: (1) An individual who is an illegal alien; (2) A corporation which is not duly qualified to do business in the state or whose proposed manager is a prohibited person under the terms of this section; (3) A person who has been convicted of a felony, of a crime opposed to decency and morality or of a crime involving the violation of any county, state or federal laws or regulations pertaining to the manufacture, possession, transportation or sale of malt beverages, wine or intoxicating liquors and served any sentence imposed following such a conviction within a period of five years prior to the date of application; (4) A person whose license has been revoked for cause or whose license for the sale of malt beverages issued by any other licensing authority has been revoked within a period of five years prior to the date of application; (5) An individual who is under the age of 21 or who is not of sound mind and memory; (6) An officer or employee of the county, or members of their immediate families; provided that the subsequent election, appointment, or employment shall not result in the revocation or prevent the renewal of a malt beverage license previously granted. (c) Prohibited locations. (1) No original retail or wholesale malt beverage license, including consumption on premises or retail package license, shall be issued under this article for any location which is within 500 feet of a church, public or private school or college campus, or a private residence on the same street unless such residence is itself in a commercial district. (2) The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Church building means the main structure used by any religious organization for purposes of worship. Private residence means a house, dwelling, condominium or duplex wherein not less than one nor more than two families reside and shall not include a mobile home park or court, an apartment house having facilities for housing more than two families, nor a boardinghouse or roominghouse where there are five or more boarders or roomers. Any building occupied as a residence located within an area zoned for business shall not be construed as a "private residence." School building or educational building means and shall apply only to state, county, city, or church school buildings and to such buildings at such other schools in which are taught subjects commonly taught in the common schools and colleges of this state and which are public schools and private schools as defined in O.C.G.A. § 20-2-690(b). (3) For purposes of this section, distance shall be measured by the most direct route of travel on the ground and shall be measured in the following manner: a. From the main entrance of the establishment from which malt beverages are sold or offered for sale; b. In a straight line to the nearest public sidewalk, street, road or highway right-of-way by the nearest route; c. Along such public sidewalk, street, road or highway right-of-way by the nearest route; d. To the nearest property line of a church building, private residence, or school grounds; e. To the front main door of the main building of a church, private residence, or school, other than the dwelling of the licensee. (4) No location which is licensed to sell alcoholic beverages on the effective date of the ordinance from which this section is derived shall be denied continued operation under an existing license, or denied any renewal of such license, nor shall any new owner of the location be denied a new license based upon the measurements set forth in this section. (5) As to any location licensed in the future, if the distance requirements in this section are met at the time of issuance of any license, the subsequent opening and operation of a church or school, or construction of a private residence within the distance prohibited in this section shall not prevent the continuance of an existing license or the renewal thereof or the issuance of a new license to any subsequent owner of such property. Provided, however, that the distance requirements shall not apply at any location for which a new license is applied if the sale of alcoholic beverages was lawful at such location at any time during the 12 months immediately preceding such application. (6) Where a license is issued to a grocery or convenience store, where the sale of malt beverages is incidental to the sale of groceries and other like items, such store shall be exempt from the provisions relating to private residences. (Res. of 1-16-1966, § 10; Res. of 12-1-1992; Res. of 6-14-2004(1), § 10; Res. of 6-14-2004(2), § 3; Ord. of 4-7-2009(1); Ord. No. 2018-09, § 1, of 6-5-2018) State Law reference— Location restrictions for sale of alcoholic beverages, O.C.G.A. § 3-3-21. Sec. 6-29. - Renewal of license; denial of renewal application; hearing. (a) All malt beverage licenses shall be issued on a calendar year basis. Each such license holder shall make written application for renewal of such license on or before December 20 of each year on forms provided by the county manager or designee. (b) All applications for renewal shall be referred to the chief of the county police who shall file a report on the activity of the licensee and the activity on the licensed premises. (c) Upon receipt of the report of the chief of the county police, the board of commissioners shall either grant or deny the renewal application. In the event the renewal application is approved, written notice thereof shall be given to the applicant and a license shall be issued upon payment of the appropriate license fee. (d) In passing upon a renewal application, the board of commissioners shall be guided by the provisions of sections 6-27 and 6-28. (Res. of 1-16-1966, § 11) Sec. 6-30. - Surrender of license. Immediately upon the discontinuance of business at the licensed premises, the holder of a malt beverage license shall surrender such license to the county manager or designee. (Res. of 1-16-1966, § 12) Sec. 6-31. - Change in ownership of licensed premises. Any holder of a license issued under the provisions of this article shall immediately report any change in the ownership or interest in the licensed premises to the county manager or designee. (Res. of 1-16-1966, § 13) Sec. 6-32. - Change in outlet manager. Any holder of a license issued under the provisions of this article shall immediately report a change of the outlet manager to the county manager or designee. (Res. of 1-16-1966, § 14) Sec. 6-33. - Suspension and revocation of licenses; grounds; notice of proposed action; hearing. (a) The board of commissioners may suspend, revoke, or place on probation any license issued under this article upon the following grounds: (1) The violation by the license holder or any employee at the licensed business location of any provision of this article, of any laws or ordinances regulating the sale and taxation of malt beverages, of any regulations promulgated pursuant to such laws or ordinances, or of any state, federal or local law or ordinance relating to the use and sale of drugs or alcoholic beverages. (2) The making of a false statement on the license application. (3) The license holder or business manager becoming a prohibited person as set forth in section 6-28. (4) Discontinuance of or closure of an outlet or business location for a continuous period of time in excess of 15 days. (5) Failure of the license holder to file timely reports, to remit proper tax, or to maintain records as required by sections 6-35 and 6-36. (6) The continued operation of the licensed business is detrimental to the health, safety or welfare of the citizens of the county. (b) Should the county manager or designee determine that probable cause exists for the suspension, revocation or placement on probation of a malt beverage license, he shall schedule a hearing thereon before the board of commissioners and cause the license holder to be served personally or by registered mail or by certified mail, return receipt requested, with notice of the time and place of hearing on the proposed action, together with a statement of the reasons therefor. Such notice shall be served at least ten days prior to the hearing. The license holder shall be allowed the opportunity to present evidence and to cross-examine opposing witnesses at the hearing. Should either party desire the hearing to be recorded, then the costs therefor shall be borne equally between the parties. The party desiring the hearing to be recorded shall secure the services of a certified court reporter and failure to do so shall not delay the hearing. After such hearing, the board of commissioners may suspend, revoke or place on probation, any malt beverage license. Its decision shall be made in writing, setting forth the reasons for such decision and shall be served upon the license holder, personally or by registered mail or by certified mail. Upon the suspension or revocation of a malt beverage license, the chief of the county police or an officer designated by him shall immediately remove the malt beverage license from the licensed premises and deliver it to the county manager or designee. (Res. of 1-16-1966, § 15) Sec. 6-34. - License fees. The following license fees shall be paid to the county manager or designee prior to the issuance or renewal of any malt beverage license: (1) Retail package store. The license fee for operation of a retail package store for one calendar year, or any part thereof, shall be $300.00. No license fee shall be prorated or refunded. (2) Pouring outlet. The license fee for operation of a pouring outlet for one calendar year, or any part thereof, shall be $350.00. No license fee shall be prorated or refunded. (3) Wholesale distributor. The license fee for operation as a wholesale distributor for one calendar year, or any part thereof, shall be $250.00. No license fee shall be prorated or refunded. (4) Alcoholic beverage caterer. The license fee for operation as an alcoholic beverage caterer for one calendar year, or any part thereof, shall be $350.00. No license fee shall be prorated or refunded. (5) Special event permit. The permit fee for each day of a special event shall be $150.00. No permit fee shall be prorated or refunded. (Res. of 1-16-1966, § 16; Res. of 6-14-2004(1), § 16; Res. of 6-14-2004(2), § 4; Res. of 8-6-2013) Sec. 6-35. - Taxation rate. In addition to any license fee imposed and required, there is hereby levied and imposed upon each wholesale dealer selling, shipping, delivering or otherwise disposing of malt beverages within this county, whether or not such wholesale dealer is licensed as a wholesale distributor in this county, an excise tax on malt beverages sold, shipped, delivered, or otherwise disposed of within this county, as follows: (1) Where malt beverages, commonly known as tap or draft beer, are sold in or from a barrel or bulk container, a tax of $6.00 on each container sold containing not more than 15½ gallons and a proportionate tax at the same rate on all fractional parts of 15½ gallons. (2) Where malt beverages are sold in bottles, cans, or other containers, except barrel or bulk containers, a tax of $.05 per 12 ounces and a proportionate tax at the same rate on all fractional parts of 12 ounces. (Res. of 1-16-1966, § 17) Sec. 6-36. - Records; availability for inspection. (a) An invoice showing the quantity of malt beverages, by size, type of container and brand name, shall be prepared in triplicate for each delivery of malt beverages to a retail package store or pouring outlet in this county by a wholesale distributor, whether such distributor is licensed in this county or another county of the state. The original invoice shall be retained by the retail package store or pouring outlet licensee and a copy retained by the wholesale distributor for a period of at least three years. Such invoices and all records maintained pursuant to state law shall be available for inspection at any time by officials authorized by the board of commissioners of the county, acting by and through the county manager or designee. (b) The holder of a license for malt beverages for consumption on premises shall produce satisfactory evidence to the county manager on a monthly basis that the business meets the percentage of food requirement as required herein. Failure to produce such evidence shall be cause for denial or revocation of the license. (Res. of 1-16-1966, § 19; ; Res. of 6-14-2004(1), § 19; Res. of 6-14-2004(2), § 7) Sec. 6-37. - Right of audit. The county shall have the right to audit, and to require production of records from each wholesale distributor supplying retailers in this county and each retail package store and pouring outlet licensed in the county. (Res. of 1-16-1966, § 20) Sec. 6-38. - Storage of inventory. Retail package store and pouring outlet licensees shall store all malt beverages in their possession only on the premises for which the license was issued. (Res. of 1-16-1966, §§ 21—23) Sec. 6-39. - Employee identification cards. (a) Condition precedent to employment. No licensee shall permit any person to work or assist in a retail package store, pouring outlet, or alcoholic beverage caterer until such person has procured a malt beverage employee identification card as provided in this section. (b) Application. Any person who intends to work for a retail package store, pouring outlet, or alcoholic beverage caterer shall apply to the county police department for a malt beverage employee identification card on such forms as approved by the board of commissioners. Such application shall contain the following information: (1) Full name, address, and age. (2) Driver's license number. (3) Social Security number. (4) A complete disclosure of any convictions or pleas of guilt or nolo contendere for violations of any state or federal law or city or county ordinance. (5) Such other information as the board of commissioners deems necessary for investigation of the applicant. (c) Fingerprints and photographing . Applicants for malt beverage employee identification cards shall be photographed and fingerprinted by the county police department as a part of their application. Applicants shall make themselves available for such photographing and fingerprinting as requested by the county police department. (d) Fee. Each application shall be accompanied by a nonrefundable application fee of $20.00. (e) Procedure for approval . The county police department shall investigate the applicant and shall file its report with the board of commissioners. The board of commissioners may either approve or deny the application for a malt beverage employee identification card. The board of commissioners may deny the application if the record indicates that approval of the application would adversely affect the public health, safety or welfare and shall deny the application if the applicant has made a material false statement on his application or is a prohibited person as set forth in section 6-28. (f) Temporary identification card . The county police may issue a temporary identification card pending final decision by the board of commissioners. In the event the application is denied, the temporary identification card shall be automatically revoked and shall be surrendered upon demand by the county police department. (1) Display of identification card on licensed premises . All malt beverage employee identification cards and temporary identification cards shall be displayed prominently at all times on the licensed premises where the holder is employed. (2) Revocation of identification card . Grounds for revocation of a malt beverage employee identification card and the procedure for revocation of such identification cards shall be the same as that set forth in section 6-33 for revocation of malt beverages licenses. (3) Surrender of identification card . A holder of a malt beverage employee identification card shall surrender it to the county police department immediately upon discontinuance of his employment at a licensed retail package store or pouring outlet and upon demand after the same has been revoked as provided in this article. It shall be unlawful for a holder to refuse to so surrender or to alter, conceal, deface or destroy such card. (Res. of 1-16-1966, § 25; Res. of 8-6-2013) Sec. 6-40. - Regulations. (a) No holder of a retail package store, pouring outlet, or alcoholic beverage caterer license, nor any agent or employee of said license holder, shall do any of the following upon the outlet premises: (1) Knowingly sell malt beverages to any underage person as provided in (O.C.G.A. § 3-3-23); (2) Knowingly sell malt beverages to any person who is in a state of noticeable intoxication; (3) Sell malt beverages or permit the consumption of malt beverages on any day or at any time when such sale or consumption is prohibited; (4) Allow any disorderly conduct, breach of the peace, or any lewd, immoral or illegal conduct, entertainment or practices on the licensed premises; (5) Allow "curb service" or the consumption of malt beverages on any parking lot adjacent to the premises. (b) Malt beverages shall be received at and delivered to the premises of a retail package store or pouring outlet licensee only by conveyance owned and operated by a wholesale distributor licensed in the county, unless said wholesale distributor is licensed in another county of this state and only delivers and receives payment in the county for malt beverages previously ordered through a representative of said wholesale distributor. (c) Each holder of a license issued pursuant to this article shall display the license prominently at all times on the premises for which the license is issued. (d) Every retail package store and pouring outlet shall post in a conspicuous place on the premises a sign in letters at least two inches high, reading, "Sale of malt beverages to minors strictly prohibited." (e) No screen, partition or other object which prevents a clear view into the interior of a retail package store from the street shall be permitted. (f) Regulations of the state department of revenue relating to the sale and distribution of malt beverages are hereby incorporated into and made a part of this article as if fully set out herein. (Res. of 1-16-1966, § 26; Res. of 8-6-2013) Sec. 6-41. - Supplemental requirements for sale of malt beverages for on-premises consumption. The area (in square feet) of a bar or lounge facility in a restaurant shall not be greater than 25 percent of the square footage of the dining area of the establishment where tables are located, excluding kitchen area, hall, restrooms, waiting area, and areas where games or other activities are located. (Res. of 6-14-2004(2), § 7) Sec. 6-42. - Hours of operation. (a) Retail package store, pouring outlets, and alcoholic beverage caterer. Malt beverages may be sold at retail package stores, pouring outlets, and alcoholic beverage caterers only between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 2:00 a.m., Monday through Friday, between the hours of 6:00a.m. and 12:00 midnight on Saturday, and between the hours of 12:30 p.m. and 11:30 p.m. on Sunday. No malt beverages shall be sold on Christmas Day or any other day prohibited by state law. (b) Limitation on pouring outlets . All pouring outlets shall be closed for business of any kind between the hours of 2:00 a.m. and 8:00 a.m., Monday through Saturday, between the hours of 12:00 midnight Saturday and 12:30 p.m. Sunday, and between 11:30 p.m. Sunday and 8:00 a.m. Monday. (c) Wholesale distributors. Wholesale distributors, whether licensed in this county or any other county in this state, may distribute malt beverages within this county only between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m., Monday through Saturday. (Res. of 1-16-1966, § 27; Res. of 6-14-2004(1), § 28; Ord. of 12-4-2012(2); Res. of 8-6-2013) Sec. 6-43. - Advertising; signs. There shall be no more than three signs advertising the sale of malt beverages on the premises of a licensee. Such signs shall be no more than eight inches in height and 24 inches in length. (Res. of 1-16-1966, § 28; Res. of 6-14-2004(1), § 29) Sec. 6-44. - Limitation of number of licenses. Notwithstanding any other provision of this article, the total number of licenses issued in the county for the retail sale of malt beverages, either retail package store or pouring outlet licenses, shall not exceed one license per 1,000 population according to the latest national census. (Res. of 1-16-1966, § 29; Res. of 6-14-2004(1), § 30) Sec. 6-45. - Licensed alcoholic beverage caterer. (a) Alcoholic beverage caterers may only operate within the unincorporated portions of Polk County, under an alcoholic beverage caterers license granted by the county, based upon the terms and conditions provided in this article. Malt beverages shall not be distributed, sold, or possessed for the purposed of sale or distribution by an alcoholic beverage caterer without a license granted by the county. All licenses issued hereunder shall be subject to all regulations, ordinances, and requirements contained in this chapter regarding alcoholic beverages generally. This license is not transferrable. (b) Eligibility for license. Any person, firm, or corporation applying for an alcoholic beverage caterer license shall be subject to the same licensing requirements applicable to an establishment licensed for consumption on the premises. Application shall be made on forms provided by the county clerk and must be accompanied by a certified check for the appropriate license fee. (c) Duration and renewal of license. Any alcoholic beverage caterer's license issued hereunder shall automatically expire on December 31 of the year of its issuance. Each licensee shall make a written application for renewal on or before December 20 of each year. (Res. of 8-6-2013) Sec. 6-46. - Special event permit. (a) A special event permit shall only be issued to special event organizers. The permit shall be valid for one day of a special event conducted by or for the benefit of certified nonprofit or civic organizations. Event organizers must specify, at the time of application, a properly licensed person, firm, or corporation that will be selling or otherwise distributing malt beverages for an event. Only persons, firms, or corporations properly licensed by the state department of revenue for the sale of malt beverages for consumption on the premises shall be permitted to provide malt beverages at a special event. Event organizers shall be limited to six days of special events in any calendar year for which a special event permit is required. Special event organizers shall make application for the permit on forms provided by the county clerk and must be accompanied by a certified check for the appropriate permit fee. Special event permits shall not be issued for special events taking place on public property. This permit is not transferrable. (b) Following each special event, the event organizer(s) shall provide to the county clerk, documented proof of the actual amount of proceeds from the event that were distributed to certified nonprofit or civic organizations. Failure to provide the required documentation shall be grounds for denying future permit applications. (c) Revocation of permit. The chief of the county police department, or his designee, may immediately revoke any special event permit if continued alcohol sales may endanger the health, welfare, or safety of the public. There will be no refunds for revoked permit. (d) Indemnification. As a condition precedent to the issuance of a special event permit, event organizers shall indemnify, in writing, and hold the county and all its departments, agencies, officials, officers, and employees forever harmless from claims, demands, or cause of actions that may arise from activities associated with any special event. (e) It shall be unlawful for any person, entity, or organization to sell, dispense, or distribute alcoholic beverages at any special event, except in accordance with this article. (Res. of 8-6-2013) Sec. 6-47. - Violations. Any person violating any provision of this chapter shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be subject to a fine of up to $1,000.00 and/or six months in jail per violation. In addition, any person violating any provision of this chapter may also have their license suspended or revoked and/or be subject to other penalties provided for in connection with violations of said license. (Res. of 8-6-2013)

div.head: Chapter 10 - ANIMALS
div.p: Sec. 10-1. - Title. This chapter shall be known as the county animal control ordinance. (Ord. of 12-2-2003, § I) Sec. 10-2. - Purpose and intent. It is the intent of this chapter to require animal owners to be responsible and accountable for the actions, behavior, and condition of their animals, to provide for the humane treatment of animals, to provide for the classification of dangerous dogs and vicious dogs, to provide for the investigation of cruelty to animals, to provide for emergency procedures pertaining to sick or injured animals, to provide for rabies control, and to promote the public health, safety and general welfare of the citizens of the county. (Ord. of 12-2-2003, § II; Ord. of 9-1-2015) Sec. 10-3. - Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Adequate food and water means food and water which is sufficient in amount and appropriate for the particular animal to prevent starvation, dehydration, or a significant risk to the animal's health from a lack of food or water. (1) Adequate food means palatable, noncontaminated, and nutritionally adequate food that is fed according to the species requirements or is fed as directed by a veterinarian. Adequate food does not include garbage. (2) Adequate water means clean, fresh, potable water offered to pets at suitable intervals according to the species requirements or as dictated by naturally occurring states of hibernation normal for the species, or as directed by a veterinarian. Adequate shelter means a dwelling that protects the animal from drafts and all forms of weather (including, but not limited to, rain, sleet, snow), and provides for shade from the heat in the summer and consists of a three sided shelter, with a roof and with a floor that supports the animal off the bare ground and includes clean, dry, bedding. Adequate temperature control means indoor housing facilities for pets are sufficiently heated and/or cooled when necessary to protect the animals from excessive heat or from chilling, freezing or from any physical damage. Except for equines, the ambient temperatures should not be allowed to fall below 45 degrees Fahrenheit or rise above 85 degrees Fahrenheit, for animals that are not acclimated. Adequate ventilation means indoor housing facilities for pets are adequately ventilated to provide for the health of the animals at all times. Such facilities must be provided with fresh air either by means of windows, vents, fans, or air conditioning and should be ventilated so as to minimize drafts, odors, and moisture condensation. Adult as it applies to dogs and cats in this document means a domestic canine over 12 months of age and a domestic feline over eight months of age. Animal means any live creature, both domestic and wild, except humans. "Animal" also includes fowl, fish and reptiles. Animal control means the animal control department of the county. Animal control officer means an employee of animal control designated to administer and enforce the requirements contained within this chapter. Animal nuisance means any nuisance arising out of the keeping, maintaining or owning of, or failure to exercise sufficient control over an animal. Animal shelter means the county animal shelter where animals impounded under the terms of this chapter shall be kept. Association means an unincorporated society, or body or persons united and acting together with a common purpose, operating without a corporate charter. It is not a legal entity separate from the persons who comprise it. At heel means a dog is directly behind or next to a person and obedient to that person's command. At large means that an animal is off the premises of the owner, and not on a leash or otherwise under the immediate control of a person physically capable of restraining the animals. Aviary means any place where birds are kept confined for breeding, boarding, or similar purposes. Cat means any cat, male or female, of pure or mixed breed. Classified dog means any dog that has been classified as either a dangerous dog or vicious dog by the animal control committee. Commissioner means commissioner of the county. County means Polk County, Georgia. For the purposes of this chapter only, it shall also mean and include any participating municipality, as the same is defined by this chapter. Cruelty means any act of omission whereby unjustifiable physical pain, suffering or death of an animal is caused or permitted, including failure to provide proper drink, air, space, shelter or protection from the elements, a sanitary and safe living environment, or nutritious food. In the case of activities where physical pain is necessarily caused, such as medical and scientific research, food processing, customary and normal veterinary and agricultural husbandry practices, pest elimination, and animal training and hunting, cruelty shall mean a failure to employ the most humane method reasonably available. Dangerous dog means any dog that: (1) Causes a substantial puncture of a person's skin by teeth without causing serious injury; provided, however, that a nip, scratch, or abrasion shall not be sufficient to classify a dog as dangerous. (2) Aggressively attacks in a manner that causes a person to reasonable believe that the dog posed an imminent threat of serious injury to such person or another person although no such injury occurs; provided, however, that the act of barking, growling, or showing of teeth by a dog shall not be sufficient to classify a dog as dangerous. (3) While off the owner's property, kills a pet animal; provided, however, that this definition shall not apply where the death of such pet animal is caused by a dog that is working or training as a hunting dog, herding dog, or predator control dog. Dead animal means any carcass or parts of a carcass of any animal. Disposition means adoption, quarantine, voluntary or involuntary custodianship or placement, or euthanasia humanely administered to an animal. "Disposition" also includes placement or sale of an animal to the general public. Dog means any dog, male or female, of pure or mixed breed. Domestic animal means dogs, cats, domesticated sheep, horses, cattle, goats, swine, fowl, ducks, geese, chickens, turkeys, confined domestic hares and rabbits, pheasants, and other birds and animals raised and/or maintained in confinement. Equine means any member of the equidae species, including horses, mules, and asses. Establishment means an established fixed or mobile unit, such as a pet shop, pasture, barn, kennel, cattery, warehouse, building, vehicle, residence or parts thereof to carry out a business or to conduct any activity for which a license is required. Exotic animal means any live monkey, alligator, crocodile, cayman, raccoon, skunk, fox, bear, sea mammal, poisonous snake, member of the feline species other than domestic cat (felis domesticus), member of the canine species other than domestic dog (canis familiaris) or any other animal that would require a standard of care and control greater than that required for customary household pets sold by commercial pet shops O.C.G.A. title 5, ch. 27 (O.C.G.A. § 5-27-1 et seq.). Facility means the physical aspects of a building or premises that is maintained, installed, or established to carry out a particular purpose. Foster home means any place routinely or in the practice of providing temporary care for animals. A foster home must be under a written contract with a licensed animal shelter. A foster home will be considered an agent for the animal shelter, and not an animal shelter itself. Garbage means all refuse matter, animal or vegetable; by-products of a restaurant, kitchen or meat/poultry processing establishment; and every refuse accumulation of animal, fruit, or vegetable matter, liquid or otherwise, that is normally discarded. For the purposes of this chapter, garbage shall not include home prepared food given to an animal living on the property of the person caring for the animal. Governing authority means the governing authority of the county. Guard or attack dog means a dog trained to attack on command or to protect persons or property, and who will cease to attack upon command. Humane care of animals means, but is not limited to, the provision of adequate heat, ventilation, sanitary shelter, and wholesome and adequate food and water, consistent with the normal requirements and feeding habits of the animal's size, species, and breed. Inhumane care means any act, omission, or neglect, which causes unjustifiable physical pain, suffering, or death to any living animal. Impoundment means the taking into custody of an animal by any law enforcement officer, animal control officer, or any authorized representative thereof. Incubate means to sit upon and hatch eggs, or to maintain eggs as embryos in a favorable environment for development and hatching. Indoor housing facility means an establishment within the interior of a building wherein all activity is conducted for which the license is issued. Kennel means any establishment, other than an animal shelter, where dogs or cats are maintained for boarding, holding, training, or similar purposes for a fee or compensation. Similar purposes include, but are not limited to, activities of a breeding establishment, cattery, or grooming shop. See Appendix A, Section 708.17 L.2. for kennel requirements. (1) Breeding establishment means any establishment where pets are bred and a fee or compensation is received for the breeding and maintenance of such pets, such as stud service. (2) Cattery means any establishment where a cat is maintained for breeding, boarding, training, holding, or similar purposes for a fee or compensation. (3) Grooming shop means any establishment, other than an animal shelter, where a person maintains a dog or cat for bathing, dipping, clipping, trimming, bushing, or similar care of the appearance for a fee or compensation. Litter means the animals born to a pet animal at one time or a clutch of nesting eggs produced and incubated by a female bird at a single sitting, or a brood of chicks incubated by mechanical means. Livestock means all animals of the equine, ruminant, fowl or swine class, including, but not limited to: chickens, roosters, goats, sheep, mules, horses, hogs, cattle, lamas, and other grazing animals, and all ratites, including but not limited to: ostriches, emus, and rheas. Maintain means to keep or keep up, or to keep in a certain condition. Minimum age to sell means at an age that no longer requires parental nurturing for survival, or at an age that can be sustained from appropriate and nutritional food given by persons who are knowledgeable in the feeding needs and eating habits common to the breed, size and age of the species. Outdoor housing establishment means an establishment outside a building and in the open air. Owner means any natural person or legal entity including, but not limited to, a corporation, partnership, firm, or trust owning, possessing, harboring, keeping or having custody or control of the animal for three or more days (regardless of whether the days follow one another); this term shall include a joint owner and the resident spouse of the person that owns the animal (because such spouse lives in the same residence and therefore has custody or control over such animal). Participating municipality means any municipality in the county which by ordinance or resolution agrees to participate in the county animal control program as set forth in this chapter through an intergovernmental agreement and which agrees to share the expenses of said program. Person means any person, firm, corporation, partnership, association, or other legal entity, any other entity, or private institution, the state, or any county, municipal corporation or political subdivision of the state. Pet means any animal that is customarily obtained as a pet and includes, but is not limited to, dog, cat, bird, equine, fish, reptile, rodent, chinchilla, rabbit, hamster, guinea pig, or miniature pig. Any animals described in O.C.G.A. §§ 27-1-2 and 27-5-5 are not considered a pet for the purposes of this chapter, except where specifically mentioned herein. Pet breeder means a pet dealer who sells, offers to sell, exchanges, or offers for adoption only pets they have produced, except equine. This includes those produced for hobby, show purposes, breed improvement, or stock replacement. Pet dealer means a person who sells, offers to sell, exchanges, or offers for adoption pets they have produced, bought, or otherwise obtained, except equine. Equine dealers require a livestock dealers' license from the Georgia Department of Agriculture. Premises means any establishment, facility, land, or parts thereof. Primary enclosure means any structure or device used to restrict an animal or animals to a limited amount of space, such as a building, room, pen, run, cage, aquarium, hutch, stall, paddock, pasture, or animal transfer vehicle. Produced means to have propagated or generated the progeny of a female. Proper animal health care means a program of disease control and prevention, veterinary care, and humane euthanasia. The animal health care should be sufficient to prevent unnecessary physical pain or suffering. Proper enclosure means an enclosure for keeping a dangerous dog or vicious dog while on the owner's property securely confined indoors or in a securely enclosed and locked pen, or structure suitable to prevent the entry of young children and designed to prevent the dog from escaping. Any such pen or structure shall have secure sides and a secure top, and must be at least 10 feet by 20 feet, and, must prevent the dog's escape either from over or from under the enclosure. Any such enclosure shall also provide protection from the elements for the dog. Public nuisance animal means any animal that unreasonably annoys humans, endangers the life or health of persons or other animals, or substantially interferes with the rights of citizens, other than their owners, to enjoyment of life or property. The term "public nuisance animal" shall include, but not be limited to: (1) Any animal that is repeatedly found running at large; (2) Any dog or cat in any section of a park or public recreation area, unless the dog or cat is controlled by a leash or similar physical restraint; (3) Any animal that damages, soils, defiles or defecates on any property other than that of its owner; (4) Any animal that makes disturbing noises, including but not limited to, continued and repeated howling, barking, whining, or other utterances causing unreasonable annoyance, disturbance, or discomfort to neighbors or others in close proximity to the premises where the animal is kept or harbored; (5) Any animal that causes fouling of the air by noxious or offensive odors and thereby creates unreasonable annoyance or discomfort to neighbors or others in close proximity to the premises where the animal is kept or harbored; (6) Any animal in heat that is not confined so as to prevent attraction or contact with other animals: (7) Any animal, whether or not on the property of its owner, that without provocation, molests, attacks, or otherwise interferes with the freedom of movement of persons in a public right-of-way; (8) Any animal that attacks domestic animals; (9) Any animal that causes unsanitary conditions in enclosures or surroundings where the animal is kept or harbored; (10) Any animal that is offensive or dangerous to the public health, safety or welfare by virtue of the number of animals maintained at a single residence or the inadequacy of the facilities. Records of an appropriate authority means records of any state, county, or municipal law enforcement agency; records of animal control; records of any county board of health; records of any federal, state, or local court; or records of an animal control officer provided for in this chapter. Rescue group means any association or corporation operated as a nonprofit organization and for the purpose of providing care and shelter to animals. Except rescue groups for equine, a rescue group that takes possession of the animals and provides care and shelter must be licensed as an animal shelter or under written contract with a licensed animal shelter, in which case it will be considered an agent for the animal shelter and not an animal shelter itself. An equine rescue group operating for that purpose and maintaining any facility (including, without limitation, providing temporary care at a person's private property) must meet all the requirements of a licensed stable. Sanitary means a condition of good order and cleanliness to minimize the possibility of disease transmission. Sanitation means the maintenance of conditions conducive to health and involves bedding changes (as appropriate), cleaning, and disinfection. Cleaning removes excessive amounts of dirt and debris, and disinfection reduces or eliminates unacceptable concentration of microorganisms. To sanitize, therefore, means to make physically clean, and to the maximum degree practical, remove and destroy agents injurious to health. Serious injury means any physical injury that creates a substantial risk of death; results in death, broken or dislocated bones, lacerations requiring multiple sutures, or disfiguring avulsions; requires plastic surgery or admission to a hospital; or results in protracted impairment of health, including transmission of an infection or contagious disease, or impairment of the function of any bodily organ. Sexually mature animal means any dog or cat that has reached the age of 180 days or six months or more. Stable means any establishment, or other enclosure where equines are maintained for boarding, holding, training, breeding, riding, pulling vehicles, or other similar purposes and a fee is charged for maintaining such equines or for the use of such equines. Sterilization means the surgical removal of the reproductive organs of a dog or cat in order to render the animal unable to reproduce. Stray cat means any cat without a collar and proof of rabies vaccination, and that is not claimed by anyone as its owner. Stray dog means any dog without a collar and proof of rabies vaccination and that is not claimed by anyone as its owner. Vicious animal means any captive animal owned by a resident that inflects serious injury on a person or pet or causes serious injury to a person or pet resulting from the animal attack. Vicious dog means a dog that inflicts serious injury on a person or causes serious injury to a person resulting from reasonable attempts to escape from the dog's attack (O.C.G.A. § 4-8-21). Wild animal means any live, nondomesticated animal, including: monkey, nonhuman primate, raccoon, skunk, fox, leopard, panther, tiger, lion, lynx, or any other warm-blooded animal that can normally be found in the wild state. The term "wild animal" does not include; domestic dogs (hybrids with wolves, coyotes or jackals are considered wild animals), domestic cats (hybrids with ocelots or margays are considered wild animals), farm animals, rodents, any hybrid animal that is part wild, and captive bred species of common cage birds. Wild animal shall also mean those animals as defined in O.C.G.A. title 5, ch. 27 (O.C.G.A. § 5-27-1 et seq.). Under restraint means that an animal is secured by a leash, lead under the control of a person physically capable of restraining the animal and obedient to that persons' commands, at heel, or securely enclosed within the real property limits of the owner's property. (Ord. of 12-2-2003, § III; Ord. of 9-1-2015) Sec. 10-4. - Caring for animals. (a) It shall be unlawful for the owner or custodian of any animal to willfully abandon such animal on any street, road, highway or public place, or on private property when not in the care of another person. (b) It shall be unlawful for any owner or custodian of any animal to permit the accumulation of waste matter from animals to collect and remain on the property of the owner or custodian or on the property of others so as to cause or create an unhealthy, unsanitary, dangerous or offensive living condition on the owner's or custodian's property, or to abutting property of others. (c) It shall be unlawful for any owner or custodian of any animal to permit or cause unsanitary, dangerous or offensive conditions by virtue of the size or number of animals maintained at a single location or due to the inadequacy of the facilities. (d) It shall be unlawful for any owner or custodian of any cat to allow the cat to run free on the property of another, without permission of the owner or person in possession of that property and without wearing a collar with an identification tag, and a current rabies tag showing that said cat has been inoculated for rabies within one year of any such time as the rabies tag may be checked. (e) It shall be unlawful for any owner or custodian of any dog to allow the dog to run free on the property of another, without the permission of the owner or person in possession of that property. (f) It shall be unlawful for any owner or custodian of any dog to allow the dog to run free without wearing a collar with an identification tag and a current rabies tag showing that said dog has been inoculated for rabies within one year of any such time as the rabies tag may be checked. (g) It shall be unlawful for any owner or lessee of property located in a residential neighborhood, regardless of the designated zoning of said property, to keep or maintain livestock in said residential area, unless the applicable zoning expressly allows otherwise. (h) No owner or custodian of any animal shall fail to exercise proper care and control of such animal to prevent the same from becoming a public nuisance. (Ord. of 12-2-2003, § IV) State Law reference— Abandoning dogs, O.C.G.A. § 4-8-3; permitting female dog to run at large, O.C.G.A. § 4-8-6. Sec. 10-5. - Emergencies involving animals. (a) Sick or injured animals. (1) In any situation deemed appropriate by the animal control officer involving a sick or injured animal whose owner cannot be located and the condition of such animal is such that death or great suffering to the animal is likely, the animal control officer may take custody of such animal and may secure veterinary services for such animal. The owner of such animal shall be responsible for reimbursement of all expenses related to treatment and boarding of the animal. (2) Any sick or injured animal, deemed by a licensed veterinarian to be suffering to such an extent that the humane destruction of the animal is appropriate and the owner of the animal cannot be located, shall be humanely destroyed by the veterinarian. (3) The owner of the animal shall be responsible for reimbursement to the county for all expenses involving the boarding, treatment, and destruction of any such animal. (b) Contagious animals. (1) Any animal impounded by the animal control officer that is, in the opinion of the animal control director, infected with a disease likely to cause death or great suffering to the animal, or which will likely spread to other animals shall be isolated and the owner of such animal shall be notified. If the owner cannot be located or the owner fails to take immediate steps to remove the animal from impoundment, the infected animal shall be humanely destroyed. (2) The owner of any such animal shall be responsible for all expenses related to the impoundment, boarding, treatment and destruction of such animal. (c) Dangerous and potentially dangerous dog. See section 10-18. (Ord. of 12-2-2003, § V; Ord. of 9-9-2014; Ord. of 9-1-2015) Sec. 10-6. - Cruelty to animals. (a) It shall be unlawful for any person to neglect to provide appropriate veterinary care to their animal when causing unnecessary pain, injury, suffering or death to an animal. (b) No person, except under the direction of a licensed veterinarian for humanitarian purposes, shall intentionally administer poison to any animal, or knowingly leave any poisonous substance of any kind or ground glass in any place with the intent to injure any animal. This provision is not applicable to licensed exterminators using poisons as part of a pest control program or the use of commercial insecticides and rodent baits used to control insects and wild rodents. (c) It shall be unlawful for any person to deprive an animal of its necessary shelter or beat, mutilate or kill any animal, or cause the same to be done, or leave unattended or carry in or upon vehicles without proper restraint or ventilation, or otherwise treat any animal in a cruel or inhumane manner. (d) It shall be unlawful to fail to maintain in a clean and sanitary condition, free from extreme and unreasonably objectionable odor, any and all structures, pens, yards and areas adjacent thereto wherein an animal is kept. (e) It shall be unlawful to fail to provide bedding and adequate shelter from the elements for any animal kept outdoors. (f) It shall be unlawful to: (1) Own, possess, keep or train any animal with the intent that such animal or any animal shall engage in an exhibition fighting. (2) Build, make, maintain or keep a pit on premises owned by him or occupied by him, or allow a pit to be built, made, maintained or kept on such premises, for the purpose of any exhibition of animal fighting. (3) In any manner encourage, instigate, promote or assist in an exhibition of animal fighting. (4) Charge admission, act as an assistant or umpire, or participate or be physically present as a spectator to any exhibition of animal fighting. State Law reference— Dog fights, O.C.G.A. § 16-12-37. (g) Any animal control officer shall impound any animal found to be cruelly treated. (h) The animal control officer shall investigate complaints pertaining to cruelty to animals. The animal control officer may request the assistance of an appropriate law enforcement officer. (i) The number of animals a person shall have possession of shall be limited to the number than can be adequately fed, watered, housed, humanely cared for, and maintained so as not to cause an act of cruelty to the animals, nor to support a public nuisance as to be determined by the animal control officer. (j) No person convicted of an act of cruelty against an animal, as defined in this chapter or in state law, shall be allowed to keep an animal of the same species as that which the act was committed against. (Ord. of 12-2-2003, § VI) State Law reference— Georgia Animal Protection Act, O.C.G.A. § 4-11-1 et seq. Sec. 10-7. - Disposal of dead animals. (a) Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: Dead animals means the carcasses or parts of carcasses of all animals, regardless of whether they are considered to be farm livestock, poultry, equine, domesticated animals, pets, or any other type of animals, and shall include all animals regardless of the cause of death of such animals, provided that nothing in this section applies to dead animals as defined in O.C.G.A. § 4-5-2. (b) Abandonment of dead animals; requirements for disposal. (1) It shall be unlawful for any person who owns or is caring for an animal which has died or has been killed to abandon the animal, its parts or blood. Such person shall dispose of the dead animal as provided for in this section. Under no conditions may dead animals be abandoned in wells or open pits of any kind on private or public land or in any type of waterway. (2) No person shall dispose of an animal, its parts or blood by burial on the land of another without the permission of the owner of the land. (3) Arrangements for proper burial must be made with a county official in order to dispose of a dead animal in a county landfill or by an approved method. (c) Removal and disposition of dead animals within rights-of-way . Any other provision of this section to the contrary notwithstanding, it shall be the duty of the animal control unit with assistance from the county or city department of transportation to remove and dispose of the carcasses of all dead animals found within the rights-of-way of all county roads maintained either totally or in part from county funds. Such carcasses or parts of carcasses shall be disposed of in a manner consistent with this section. (d) Methods of disposal of dead animals. Methods which can be used for disposal of dead animals are burial and incineration in a county approved incinerator. Disposal of animal carcasses by either of the approved methods must be completed within 12 hours after death or discovery of the carcass. If incineration is chosen, the entire carcass must be reduced to ashes in the incineration process. Carcasses which are buried must be buried at least three feet below the ground level but no more than eight feet and have not less than three feet of earth cover over the carcass. (Ord. of 12-2-2003, § VII) State Law reference— Dead Animal Disposal Act, O.C.G.A. § 4-5-1 et seq.; dumping dead dogs, O.C.G.A. §§ 4-5-1, 4-5-2. Sec. 10-8. - Motorist hitting domestic animal to make report. Any person who, while operating a motor vehicle, strikes or causes injury to any domestic animal shall notify the owner if known or ascertainable, as well as the animal control unit, or appropriate police department, of the injury to and location of animal. (Ord. of 12-2-2003, § VIII) Sec. 10-9. - Female cats in heat. Every female cat in heat shall be confined in a building or other enclosure in such a manner that such female cat cannot come into contact with another animal except for planned breeding and to prevent becoming a public nuisance. (Ord. of 12-2-2003, § IX) State Law reference— Permitting dogs in heat to run at large, O.C.G.A. and 4-8-6 Sec. 10-10. - Restraint of guard dog. (a) Every owner of a guard or attack dog shall keep such dog confined in a building, compartment or other secure enclosure. Any such enclosure shall be completely surrounded by a fence at least six feet in height and shall be topped with an anticlimbing device constructed of animal metal braces with at least three strands of equally separated barbed wire stretch between them. A minimum 12 inches by 18 inches sign, visible from 30 feet, shall be posted to notify the public that a guard dog is on duty. (b) All anticlimbing devices shall extend inward at an angle of not less than 45 degrees nor more than 90 degrees when measured from the perpendicular. (c) The areas of confinement shall all have gates and entrances thereto securely closed and locked, and all fences properly maintained and escapeproof. (d) The provisions of this section shall not apply to dogs owned or controlled by government law enforcement agencies. (Ord. of 12-2-2003, § XI) Sec. 10-11. - Hunting dogs. Hunting dogs in the custody of persons hunting in accordance with state game and fish department laws, rules and regulations are exempt from the mandates of section 10-7. The owners of such dogs shall continue to be civilly liable for any damage occasioned by the actions of their dogs. While hunting, all hunting dogs shall wear a collar with identification tags as well as a current rabies vaccination tag. (Ord. of 12-2-2003, § XII) Sec. 10-12. - Return of animal to owner. If the name of the owner of an animal found at large is known or can be obtained with reasonable dispatch, the animal control officer shall return the animal to the residential address of the owner. If there is no one present, the officer shall impound the animal and leave written notice of whom the owner must contact to reclaim the animal. The owner shall be cited for violation of this chapter. (Ord. of 12-2-2003, § XIII) Sec. 10-13. - Impoundment. (a) In addition to any other remedies provided in this chapter, the animal control officer may seize and impound at the animal shelter any of the following animals: (1) Any dog or cat without a valid rabies tag and identifying tag; (2) Any animal constituting a public nuisance or considered a danger to the public as determined by the animal control officer; (3) Any animal in violation of any quarantine or confinement order issued by the county board of health or the public health director; (4) Any unattended animal that is ill, injured or otherwise in need of care; (5) Any animal that is believed to have been abused or neglected as determined by the animal control officer; (6) Any animal that is reasonably suspected of having rabies; (7) Any animal that a court of competent jurisdiction has ordered impounded or destroyed; (8) Any animal that is considered unattended or abandoned, as in situations where the owner is deceased or has been arrested or evicted from his regular place of residence and there is no other person who will take custody of the animal. (b) The animal control officer or appropriate law enforcement officer may also, or in lieu of impoundment, issue to the owner a notice of violation. Such notice will cite the owner to appear on a date certain before the magistrate court of the county as provided in this chapter. (c) Any person finding an animal at large upon his property may remove the same to the animal shelter or hold the animal in his own possession, and as soon as possible, notify animal control. The property owner shall provide a description of the animal and the name of the owner, if known. Animal control shall dispatch an animal control officer to take possession of the animal as soon as possible. (d) Any animal control officer or other designated person who seizes and impounds an animal that cannot be housed at the animal shelter shall be authorized to arrange transportation of the animal to a farm or other appropriate facility which agrees to accept such animal. The disposition of the animal shall be handled in the same manner as though the animal were confined at the animal shelter except that, in addition to the fees charged for redemption, the owner shall also pay the actual transportation and feeding costs incurred while said animal was impounded. (e) Any animal control officer or other person who discovers or is notified of livestock (as that term is defined in O.C.G.A. § 4-3-2) running at large, shall notify the appropriate law enforcement agency. The seizure, impoundment and disposition of such livestock shall be in accordance with the provisions of O.C.G.A. title 4, ch. 3 (O.C.G.A. § 4-3-1 et seq.). (Ord. of 12-2-2003, § XIV; Ord. of 9-1-2015) Sec. 10-14. - Notice to owner and redemption. (a) Upon impoundment of an animal, other than dogs believed to be subject to classification as a dangerous or vicious dog, the department of animal control shall immediately attempt to notify the owner, if known, by telephone, certified mail or by leaving of a written notice at the owner's residence. The notice to the owner shall include the location of the shelter, hours during which the animal can be reclaimed, and fees to be charged to the owner. The owner shall also be advised that the failure to claim the animal within five days following the posting or mailing of the notice may result in the disposition of the animal. If the owner is unknown, the department shall post a written notice as to where the animal was found at the animal shelter where public notices are posted for a minimum period of five days following the impoundment of an animal. (b) An owner reclaiming an impounded animal shall pay a fee for each day the animal is impounded as a boarding fee, and the actual veterinary costs. The daily rate charged for any subsequent impoundment occurring within 12 months shall be double that which was charged for each day of confinement during the first impoundment. (c) Any animal not reclaimed by its owner within five working days shall become the property of the county. (Ord. of 12-2-2003, § XV; Ord. of 9-1-2015) Sec. 10-15. - Keeping of nondomestic exotic wild animals. (a) It shall be unlawful for anyone to own, harbor, or permit at large any exotic animal within the areas of the county without the written permission of the director of animal control who may impose upon the owner reasonable conditions of confinement to assure the protection and safety of the general public. (b) It shall be unlawful to purchase, sell, own, possess or harbor any skunk, fox, prairie dog, raccoon, or other animals prohibited by DNR, in the county. (Ord. of 12-2-2003, § XVI) Sec. 10-16. - Nuisances. It shall be unlawful for any person to keep any animal on any property when the keeping of such animal constitutes a public nuisance or menace to public health or safety as determined by the animal control director. (Ord. of 12-2-2003, § XVII) Sec. 10-17. - Damage to property. It shall be unlawful for any person's animal to cause damage to another person's property. Property shall include, but not be limited to, pets, livestock, vehicles, etc. (Ord. of 12-2-2003, § XVIII) Sec. 10-18. - Dangerous dog and vicious dog control.
